item.name: 1861: The Railways of the Russian Empire
item.comment: 18xx system in Russia... with a stock market. Need I say more? Very similar to the rest of the 18xx games, with a different setting and a few slightly different rules and/or additions.

My first 18xx game. Although the game takes a long time to complete, it is not a "long" game, as there is always something for you to do, like planning out your next move, or which stocks you will be buying/selling, not to mention budgeting for that next train upgrade.

item.name: 24 Trading Card Game
item.comment: Played 2-player game using the Start Deck only. I was not impressed, and the deck limit of 24 cards it a tad low. Game play was OK, cards look nice, but something just appears to be missing.

item.name: 51st State
item.comment:
How difficult is it to make a player aid?? This one is screaming for one. Had to keep referring to the manual to understand the iconography.
Probably required a few plays to understand the mechanic, but found there was too much luck. If the cards you need don't come up, you will go through the motion but still finish in last place. Will you have fun playing? If you like going back to the rulebook to check the icons from the cards, sure, but I'll pass.

item.name: Acquire
item.comment: The mechanics in this game are interesting. I'm surprised this came out in '62. Played on of the later version, with the plastic board & place holders. Had a good time.

item.name: After the Flood
item.comment:
Only played one game, and the point spread was rather large... Mechanics seem a bit odd, especially the armies, which appear Ã -la [thing=224][/thing], except the armies disappear at the end of every turn... Felt more like a sub-game, although this IS how one scores VPs prior to turn 5.
The dice combat system seemed useless and adds randomness in order to force players to expend resources.
Will probably be replaying this again, to see if we did something wrong, as this one really did not impress me (which usually means it will not be played again).

item.name: Age of Discovery
item.comment: Resources management, set building. Very quick game, fairly nice components.

item.name: Age of Empires II
item.comment:
This one is difficult to rate, as it appears to be a good game at first glace. It has interesting mechanics, worker placement, research, resource collecting and hand management.
However, it appears to drag. The combat system is rather complex for a card game. Suggestions of using a pen and paper to track resources indicates, to me, that play testing was limited, as a simple grid and 4 resource counters would suffice to track this.
Not so with the military units, which may contain from 1 to 5 "units", therefore we used a die for this (who doesn't have a bucket of dice?).
Be ready to spend several hours for your first game, just to understand the basic concept. If you can weather that, then I am sure you will be able to find an interesting game in here, as you are able to customize your deck.
The sad thing is that this one had great potential, but there are better card games of this type out there who currently do a better job. Still, with the right card mix and clearer rules, this one could have been good.

item.name: Age of Empires III: The Age of Discovery
item.comment:
I was surprised by this one, as you have to make difficult choices most of the time. All the mechanics appear to work well together, and they fit the theme.
There are multiple ways to win, and adapting your plan to maximize you every action is key.
The game board, counters and cards are nice. The miniatures look good but are a tad too colorful (some people will have trouble with the green and blue). The coins are simply awesome!!
On the down side, the point track around the board could have been done much better. Why not stop at 100 points and have bigger and wider areas? As it is, you're better to go to paper, which is too bad.
Would have rated this one a '8.5', but the small and narrow point track drops it to an '8'.
Says on the back of the box that it's "Expandable to six players"... So when will the 6th player expansion come out?
item.wantpartslist: Looking for any/all parts for AoE III

item.name: Age of Gods
item.comment:
Where's the game? You don't know what your objectives are until 3/4 of the game is over. Each turn you select a source and a target, roll a die and hope for 3 or more to win... Oh yeah, one of the actions you did previously probably helped someone who just found out his/her objective was to grow that race. Since you don't know what your objectives are, it is rather difficult to block someone else from achieving his/her objective as he/she don't know what it is either. A waste of 2 hours of your life.
Got rid of this stinker.

item.name: Age of Mythology: The Boardgame
item.comment:
I enjoyed the Permanent/Random deck mechanic as well as the nice components, and the interesting resource system.
The combat system has unfortunately soured my experience with this game.
IMHO, they would have been better off with a system similar to Axis & Allies, as I cannot understand how 1 or 2 units can wipe out an opposing army of 6 units, repeatedly. This is not to mention that the players not engaged in the battle have nothing to do until the end of combat, which can last 5-10 minutes, as combat is conducted 1 unit at a time.
This approach provides an unfair advantage to better units, as it removes the possibility of overwhelming them with cheaper units (i.e. there can be no strenght in numbers with this system).
Last but not least, I'm not interested in playing Rock-Paper-Scisors for 2 hours.

item.name: Age of Renaissance
item.comment:
A good civilization building game, but it will probably be too long for many. Learning curve may be steep at first, so expect 1-2 games just to get a good grasp of what you need to do (and when). The Misery track can be quite problematic when you don't know which event(s) will send you plummeting down...
Combat system requires a dice roll, which some purists may not like, and even though I lost countless battles, it did not bother me (I prefer this to knowing in advance that my attack will be successful, as it removes some of the analysis-paralysis as players try to maximize everything).

item.name: Age of Steam
item.comment:
Finally got to play my first game with the correct rules! Nice components, and although I like economic games, this one simply did not work for me, as I found myself playing last way too often (6 turns out of 8!). Not being able to afford to stay in the bidding race essentially meant that the game was already over, as the only available options would not help me catch up with the leaders. Would work better if it used a system such as POWER GRID, where the last player gets to choose first.
Do note that I played with experienced players, and we had a runaway leader. By turn 4 the game was already decided, so the last hour+ was pointless. The bidding for the turn order killed it for me, and the randomness of the goods draw did not help. Rating reflects the fact that I am not interested in playing this again. If you have the 12 hours or more needed to learn to become more competitive, then perhaps this game could be of interest to you. For me, there are too many better alternatives. The lengthier 18xx games are, in my opinion, clearly better.

item.name: Agricola
item.comment:
Talk about limited actions and the desire to do more. Not for the faint of heart as the game will usually be a solid 2-3 hours. Not to be played with folks who suffer from Analysis-Paralysis!
In this one you need to find the right combos which will yield you the best results. The cards passed at the start of the game ensure good replay value, but I found they limited your options. Then again, it forces everyone to adopt different strategies.
Played twice with 5-players and did not enjoy the experience. The initial card handout will provide some players with an advantage. Game is probably best with 4, as it is too tight with 5. Was unable to get my strategy going due to the options being very limited. Game ended with the leaders essentially doubling three of the five players! 36-34-21-20-20.
Play with 4 and it was much better. Raised my rating, and am looking forward to trying it again, with 4.

item.name: Les Ailes de la Gloire
item.comment:
This is a good WWI air combat game, in 2D. Although simplistic, there are still a lot of strategies possible.
"Canvas Eagles", which is based on this game, adds altitude and flight constraints, which makes the game more appealing to those who prefer 3 dimensional air combat.

item.name: Alhambra
item.comment:
This is an OK game. I've played with up to 6 players and find the sweet spot is 4. Anything above 4 and it becomes rather chaotic (can't really plan ahead), and less than 4 is good if all the players are relatively at the same level of experience (else the point spread will turn you away from this game).
Rating dropped from 7 to 6 following a 3 player game which ended with a 60 point spread between the 2nd and 3rd player... I prefer games which are closer, where the last player has a chance to gain ground.

item.name: Alhambra: The Vizier's Favor
item.comment: The expansions in this one add some intersting twists to the base game. Highly recommended!

item.name: Alien Frontiers
item.comment:
After reading the rules, thought it was similar to KINGSBURG, but this is NOT the case, as rolling higher numbers does not ensure you get better resources.
As player dice STAY ON THE BOARD between turns, it is possible to partially block, or affect the "cost" of playing a certain action.
Since what you rolled limits your available choices of actions, it makes it difficult to plan ahead, as all you can do is choose a general direction and hope things don't change too much until your turn comes around again.
Still, it is next to impossible to be blocked, as there are tech cards which have various powers that you can use, which allows you to bend certain rules, modify the die results, re-roll, etc.
I like the fact that you can make the game longer by playing with 8 Colony tokens per players. My group found 6 tokens was just a bit too long, but after a few more plays, it should clock in the listed time.
Further, there is a 5th player expansion, which I may not pick up as it would make the game too long. But the option will be there for those who prefer 5-player games and/or have more time to play.
All in all, a nice design which leaves enough decision making, where players are not cornered, but where there is still a good deal of luck (die rolling). As I mentioned, this can be mitigated with the right cards and card combos!
The area majority on the planet, which gives you points and a special card/power if you have a majority, is simple, and seems to work fine.
The only negative aspect is the rulebook, which is missing a few important cross-references, and where some of the important rules should have been listed in bold and/or highlighted, so they could be easily referenced.
As an example, where it says that your dice stay on the table between turns, perhaps a little highlighting might have shown this to be a key rule of the game.
The Data Crystal exception regarding the Burroughs Desert should also have been listed under the Burroughs Desert section, else people would think that the Alien die will keep changing hands. Actually, this puts more importance on the territory at the center of the board, where I would expect folks try to prevent a majority.
Looking forward to trying this again, now that we seem to have figured out all the fiddly details we missed on our first go.

item.name: Anno 1503
item.comment:
This is a faily straight forward game. I like the part where one needs to accomplish 3 out of 5 objectives in order to win. On the down side, there is little player interaction, and one cannot prevent another player from building his settlers/pioneers/townsfolks/merchants, not any other objective for that matter.
The resource cards could have been replaced by cubes instead, as they would have been easier to pick up (they could be hidden in your hand).

item.name: Antike
item.comment:
Multiple paths to victory. The wheel mechanic makes for very quick turns, and provides the players with good control over their own destiny. Next to no down time when playing with 4 players! Components are of excellent quality, and I really liked the starting position/Cities cards and player aids.
The technology grid is easy to play with, and does not confer an unfair advantage to the first person to develop it (although they do get the personality card, i.e. 1VP).
Game plays faster than MARE NOSTRUM, excludes exchanges, and does not suffer as badly from leader bashing. I would prefer randomized combat, but I found the 1:1 exchanges worked surprisingly well.
Game is a tad pricey at 51 euros, but well worth the investment as it will see a lot of table time. Recommended!
item.conditiontext: MINT - in original shrink wrap

item.name: Apples to Apples
item.comment: An easy going game which can be fun to play if with the right group. The "judge" draws a green card/topic, and every player plays one of his/her cards up side down, the "judge" deciding which card most resembles the topic, according to him/her.

item.name: Arena Maximus
item.comment: A surprisingly good little game. There is a bit of "magic", but the movement system works well and the game offers a good challenge. It cool to be able to attack the other players and through them off their game.

item.name: Ark Extra Mix
item.comment: Adds some interesting animals, but still a brain burner as there are sooo many restrictions on placement!

item.name: Arkadia
item.comment:
I'm not really into Tetris type games. When placing buildings, I always seemed to be helping someone out. If I tried to get points, the next player would be able to score even more points... Don't think I'll be playing this one again.
The pieces are nice though, except for the four flags which hang from your player screen, they are too thin.

item.name: Arkham Horror
item.comment:
This is a good game, when played with the right people. When everyone pays attention to what's going on, and think ahead of their moves, the game plays relatively fast.
If you like having multiple items, spells, et cetera, then this game is for you.
Regarding the references to die rolling, there is indeed a lot, as all 'challenges' are resolved via die roll (compared to your character's rating).

item.name: Arkham Horror: Dunwich Horror Expansion
item.comment: Adds more cards, monsters, another board and some additional rules. Travelling from town to town (Arkham - Dunwich) is done via the Train station. The base game's board and the expansion's have a different background color (the first is dark, the second is light).

item.name: Ascension: Deckbuilding Game
item.comment:
I was happily surprise by this one. Yes, it's another "deck building" type game, but this one is bare bones, and works remarkably well.
Only played one game, which ended in a Triple tie in first place (51 points), with the last player no more than 5 points behind.
The tie breaker is the reverse order of the turn order, but we decided to call it a tie nonetheless.
I did not like the graphics/images, but that just personal taste. The game play itself is fairly straight forward, especially if you have played other "deck building" type games before.
I liked the row of 6 cards where you can purchase as many cards as you have money, and kill as many monsters as you have attack points. And there were plenty of "banish" cards which allowed you to thin out your deck.

item.name: Asia Engulfed
item.comment: My first impression was that this was a pretty clean system, which provides a good feel for the period. Some of the rules lead the game down a historical path, but this is more on the resource level, where the Japanese were struggling with a dwindling oil supply. The transport pool is also straight forward and adds flavor to the game. The only thing I did not like were the dice (which says a lot!)

item.name: At the Gates of Loyang
item.comment:
A brain burner with a lot of down time. Essentially a game of resource swapping... Way too long for what it is (over 2.5 hours + 30 minutes of rules explanations).
Card selection mechanic is interesting but does not alleviate the randomness issue. Essentially you need to wait and hope that someone will lay down the card you are looking for. If you have two good cards in hand, you have to take a chance and lay one down and hope no one selects it so you may select it on your next pass... A weird approach for a card draft mechanic.
Once a player falls behind, there is next to no chance of getting back into the game, as the interaction is somewhat limited (and convoluted with 4-players and the aweful "partner" rule, where you may only interact, negatively, with the "partner" selected).
Score: 19-19-17-15 For the player at "15", he/she needed 16+17 (30) coins to join 3rd place, and another +18+19 (70) to tie with first... When you are generating a little over 20 per turn, you are somehow 3 turns behind the leaders, and are not generating enough cash to have a chance to catch up. Loans could work, but the cost renders it useless as the price is a FULL point PER 5 coins at the END of the game, per card. OUCH.
In a 4-player game, the "Con Man" card is next to impossible to target, as a quadruple planet alignment needs to occur first. This card works better in a 3-player game, where there is no "partner" limitation.
Don't expect to play this again, and canceled my order.

item.name: Atlantic Star
item.comment: A card set building game, where one needs to "purchase" one of four cards in an attempt to build different sets (4 different "cruises"). Game plays fairly easily and fast.

item.name: Attack!
item.comment:
The basic game is similar to "Risk" with an advanced combat system, greater variety of units, and a wider choice of possible actions. The advanced game, which forces players to decide which actions one will make via the use of Oil Reserve Certificates (1st action costs 1 Oil, 2nd costs 2 Oil for a total of 3, etc.) is better, IMHO.
The ground and naval combat systems are also interesting and are quickly resolved. The naval combat is somewhat unrealistic and gives the defender an advantage he should not have (limiting the number of ships which can engage in combat).
There are some loopholes in the system, namely the unsinkable lone Battleship.
The worst aspect of the game is the "down time" between player turns. In a 5-player game, we have seen up to one hour go by before a player gets to do his turn!?! The "Action Card" approach proposed by a player on BGG is, IMO, a very good suggestion which could alleviate this problem.
item.conditiontext: Shrink - prefer to trade as a set with expansion

item.name: Attack! Expansion
item.comment: Combined map is 5' wide, which just fits on my gaming table.Naval combat is too simplistic and gives the defender an advantage (limiting number of units which can engage his) he should not have.Lone Battleship is unsinkable.Oil Certificate system to limit one's actions/options is good.Use of Submarines as commerce raiders is interesting.Land combat system provides bonus for combined arms approach.An interesting game, but too much downtime when played with more than 4 players.
item.conditiontext: Shrink - Prefer to trade as a set with base game.

item.name: Auf Kurs
item.comment:
It's very easy to go "Auf Kurs" (off course) in this one. The pieces look great, but I'm not a big fan of games like this, as they run a bit too long for what they are.
There are no random factors in this game, everything is controlled by the players. Some cool mechanics at play here, but just does not get to me.

item.name: Automobile
item.comment:
As always, like the mechanics Martin comes up with. Components are top notch except for the paper money (why go back to that??). Asking price is outrageous, unfortunately. :(
Still, a good euro game.

item.name: Ave Caesar
item.comment:
A blocking game where one can be forced to skip multiple turns as player after player blocks you in (oh joy!), where the designer felt the need to implement a mechanic which forces the leader to change (leader may not play any 6 value cards), so leading throughout the race is not possible.
In my last game, the leader had to wait a few turns while the 2nd player caught up, as he could not play any of his THREE "6"s... It's sad when the play of a single card would secure the win, but because you can't play a 6, you have to wait two turns for a player to pass you, then he/she plays again to win, and you finish 2nd or 3rd... Way too artificial for my tastes.
One needs to manage his cards (hand of three) as you have just about enough to go around the track three times. If you always take the outside/long route, then forget it as you won't have enough cards to make it. Feels too much like a Knizia game....
An interesting mechanic, but for me it does not work in a race setting as it is way too artificial. And the price was outrageous for what you get.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment: A fast playing light war game.

item.name: Axis & Allies
item.comment:
This is still an interesting game, although a bit long. The modifications from the 1981 are mostly good, but I would have preferred a LARGER board!
Tried a "Major Victory" game, where one side needed to Capture four Capitals, but after 8 hours, we called the game. It had become obvious the Axis would loose as the American navy had surrounded Japan, and the German attack against Russia had stalled. With the Allies controlling the seas, the end for the Axis was inevitable (minus some terrible die rolling).

item.name: Axis & Allies Miniatures
item.comment:
Although it first appeared to be a dicefest, the truth turned out to be quite different, as there is a good game in here.
Perhaps the units are not perfect and the colors may be off, but it's way better then some of the wargames I have seen in the past (Memoir 44 being the exception, for me). :)
The collectibility can be annoying, so why not pick one side and trade the other units with another gamer who would prefer the other (side). It could actually be enjoyable.
BTW, the Tiger I is very expensive to field, so you'd be better off with a less expensive tank. Too bad there are no Panzer III's in this set. I look forward to the next three sets!!

item.name: Axis & Allies Naval Miniatures: War at Sea
item.comment: Battle results are believeable, it's fast playing as ship facing has no impact (so forget crossing the "T"). A 100 point fleet is too small, unless you'd like to do CL and DD engagements... Still, a single BC can whip a group of CL and DD's, no problem (unless the dice God is not with you).The collectability part is a real pain, making this a money pit. I purchased a starter and a sealed case (12 boosters), and only had about 520 points per side. Picked up a second sealed case, and am still missing 5 rare units. After all, there are 24 rare units in the set, so 24 boosters is the minimum you need to purchase if you'd like to have all the units (without going thru eBay).Another odd factor is the uncommon units. Since there are only FIVE units in a booster, three are common, 1 is uncommon, and 1 is rare, there is not much difference between rare and uncommon, or so one would think.
item.conditiontext: Have the following available for trade: #32 USS TENNESSEE, #33 USS WASHINGTON Looking for: #22 USS BALTIMORE, #27 USS IOWA, U-510 If interested in trading, please send me a private message

item.name: Axis & Allies: Guadalcanal
item.comment:
Yet another variation of the Axis & Allies system. This one places the emphasis on Naval and Air combat, to the point were infantry only plays a figurative role (majority dictates who "controls" the island).
Game appears to degenerate into a slugfest in the center of the board. There does not appear to be much room for tactics, and the artilery piece, which is both used as a majority piece on land an a canon versus ships in adjacent sea zones, is way too powerful for its cost (2).
Will be playing this one again to see if my opinion will change (I have been playing A&A and its variants since 1981).

item.name: Axis & Allies: Battle of the Bulge
item.comment:
Game is somewhat long (3-4 hours). The combat system is refreshing, but requires a lot of die rolling. I'm not a big fan of using D12's, but can understand the need to do so to make the hit allocation system work.
Unfortunately I found the game ends as soon as the allied air units (3:1) come into play, as they just pulverize everything in sight, and there is little which can be done to stop them.
Will be re-reading the rules and trying this one again to see if we missed anything.

item.name: Axis & Allies: Europe
item.comment: Same old A&A, but for some reason it doesn't grab me like the original version. I was expecting the "Battle for the Atlantic" to add more spice, but it is easily countered by an American Sub force, which is totally ahistorical. Would be much better if the American was not allowed to build subs.

item.name: Bakong
item.comment:
A 30-45 minute filler. Rather light, with a good deal of luck. Luck may be mitigated by picking up certain objects.
Player with the most Emeralds (points) wins.

item.name: BANG!
item.comment:
A very interesting and fast playing card game. Players get to "defend" by hiding being a barel or playing "missed" cards.
Played with 5 players and everyone enjoyed it. Will be playing this one again soon. :)
May 19th 2005: Increased rating to '9'. Folks are now begging me to play! :)

item.name: BANG! A Fistful of Cards
item.comment: BANG! with an added twist...and a time clock.

item.name: BANG! Dodge City
item.comment: Makes the game a bit longer, but does add some interesting cards, as well as the green bordered cards/mechanic.

item.name: BANG! High Noon
item.comment: Is more of a time clock, but it does add some variety to the game by adding a "special" power/action/event each turn.

item.name: Basari
item.comment:
Fairly easy game to play, with some player negotiations. There is some luck involved (die rolling to move your pawn), and everyone gets to pick one of three actions (hidden via the use of a card) to determine which action you will make (if two players selected the same action, the need to negotiate to determine who will get to do the action, but if there are three or more who picked the same card, none get to do the action).
At the end of each of the three rounds (moving your pawn around the board), majority is checked for each type of gem, and points are awarded.

item.name: Battleground
item.comment: A good miniatures game, for less then the cost of a blister! The system is pretty straight forward, and the cards are well made. I have a problem with writting on the cards though, even with a water soluble marker...

item.name: Battlegroup
item.comment:
I find this one better than NAVAL BATTLES, although the luck element can and does have a big impact on the game. Still, one can be rewarded for planning an attack by waiting a few turns to get the cards needed. Other times, a quick strike may bag you a few points.
The game can be a bit long, but once players know the cards, it should be a bit faster.
The Catalina-PBY card (?) which allows you to grab two cards from your opponent is too powerful. Perhaps having your opponent discard two cards randomly would work better, or drawing one card. But since this is a hand management game, taking two cards away equals a 4 card differential, which is quite substantial. Of course, if the same player draws the two PBY cards... Not to mention Radio Triangulation...
Last but not least, there are card combos which can be quite good. Overall, the game is interesting, but not quite enough to make it to a 7, IMHO.

item.name: BattleLore
item.comment:
This is a good game. Played with the basic rules, which means no magic. It's medieval combat, using the COMMANDS & COLORS: ANCIENT system, with a few minor changes. DoW did an awesome job with the pieces, as they are made of sturdy yet flexible plastic which is perfect for paint.
The rest of the production is of top quality, from the full color perfect bound 80 page rulebook, the scenario book, the counters, the plastic playing pieces and the double sided board (one side is divided for "Overlord" type setup, so two boards would have 3 sections as opposed to 6, for those of us who like epic battles!).
As opposed to GMT's approach of using hardwood blocks, DoW went with generic units which all have a socket for a flag. One differentiates the units with flags, one flag per 3-4 pieces, depending on type. Of course there are light, medium and heavy Infantry and Cavalry, along with archers. Long swords and short swords, bow and crossbows.
Definitely a must have for those who enjoyed C&C:A and like the Medieval period, as well as those looking for a more challenging game than M'44. Highly recommended!
item.conditiontext: Shrink - Note: box has a split corner (will also provide a copy of the "BattleLore Primer" booklet)

item.name: Battlestar Galactica
item.comment:
Get ready to be immersed in this theme heavy coop game where you are sure at least one of your shipmates is a Cylon!
It is a risk and resource management game, which is fairly easy to play, and where the action takes place during the Crisis Resolution step at the tail end of every player's turn. Most of the time, players will get to "vote" (using their action cards) on the crisis at hand.
WARNING: As with most games, it can be quite boring when played with the wrong type of players. Even more so with this one. Table talk is a large part of the game, so if you don't like Co-Op games or dislike the theme, stay away.
Following a jump, there will be a few duller moments. This is the time when you will want to pick up additional cards or use Recon Patrol to help with the next jump or ensure nothing really nasty is waiting for you with the next Crisis card.
NEGATIVE ASPECT: Can be long if you're not into this type of game or dislike the theme.
The Skill cards are too small (standard sized cards would have been better, IMHO)
A die would have been better when rolling to damage the Galactica (location) and/or Cylon BaseStar, instead of having to shuffle a pile of tokens.

item.name: Battlestar Galactica: Exodus Expansion
item.comment:
Cylon Fleet is a MUST and makes the Fighter Pilot's role more interesting.
Not sure about the conflicting loyalties and Ionian Nebula, as there is already too much to do... Will need to try this again, but after one try, would rather stay away from these.

item.name: Battlestations
item.comment:
This is a light role playing space combat game where each player takes the role of a crew member aboard a starship.
The Damage allocation system is interesting, damage being assigned to the various modules based on the direction from which the hit/missile came from, then penetration damage is spread across other modules in a straight line (except for missile hits which are represented by damage to adjoining modules instead).
I also liked the idea of allowing the players a free reroll when doing a skill check in their specialization.
On the negative side, the game can get repetitive, as one continuously moves between stations. This also negatively impacts the speed of the game.
The rules contain some inconsistencies and some abilities/actions may be misleading because flavor text was used.
This one came close to an '8', but for the above reasons a '6' is more appropriate.

item.name: Battlestations: Galactic Civil War
item.comment:
I was expecting a self contained campaign, but this was [u]not[/u] the case. Each mission is rolled for individually, and players get to choose one of two possible missions.
As with the missions in the base game, I found they often did not contain all the information required, and a lot of extra info needed to be added. Got the impression the missions were a work in progress...

item.name: Bean Trader
item.comment:
First off, this game is different from BOHNANZA, so don't expect to plant beans! You will be filling bean orders here, so you'll need to purchase/trade for what you need. The movement mechanic is interesting, in that cards are laid down in order to move - special cards are actioned when then come up, so you might have to pay a Toll ($20) or there might be a harvest.
Players need to manage both moves and beans, and must maximize profits and minimize movement. You will need to purchase beans you don't necessarily need in order to have something to trade/deal with other players.
The randomness some claim to see in this one can be overcomed by a bit of thinking/planning and by negotiating an invitation to trade (cost = 1 card).
If at all possible, try to negotiate with other players to trade one or two turns down the road, based on the Cities you will be visiting (to deliver an order), thus for beans you will have the potential of purchasing to trade with them.
If you don't like thinking, planning, trading/dealing games, this one is not for you.

item.name: Before the Wind
item.comment: A lot of underhanded bidding can occur in this one! When played with the right people, the game balances itself out (there is a bit of randomness). Multiple paths to victory.
item.conditiontext: MINT - in original shrink wrap

item.name: Belfort
item.comment:
Nice components, straightforward game play.
Worker placement, economy building, area majority game.
Elves, Dwarves and Gnomes... The setting/theme does noting for me.
Catching up to the leader(s) may prove rather difficult... Even with the most revenue (Gold) and workers, I finished last, even though I was building one building per turn... Something does not work for me in this game, and I just can't put my finger on it at this time. Will probably try it again at some point.

item.name: Beowulf: The Movie Board Game
item.comment:
Not to be confused with Reiner Knizia's [gameid=119], from which it stems.
Actually, it is an improved [gameid=119] with a different slapped on theme.
There are a few added twists such as tiles which can be removed, 3 boards, 3 different set of tiles (one per board).
FFG did a good job with the components, but sadly, it remains too close to the original to be that much better.

item.name: Betrayal at House on the Hill
item.comment:
An Ok game where the first part (pre-haunt) is a race to explore a house and gather items. The second part (haunt) is triggered following a failed throw versus the number of Omen cards in play. A traitor is then revealed and the players find out what their mission will be.
The game can be fairly fast. Combat is unforgiving, as attacker or source will receive a certain amount of damage based on the differential of their dice throw.

item.name: Big City
item.comment: Very nice components and good theme. A tad on the light side.

item.name: Blood Feud in New York
item.comment:
Expanding one's area of control can be difficult as your opponents may use limos, boats and/or helicopters to move their units.
Game is a bit long, but plays well. Uses an enhanced Axis & Allies Combat mechanic, which makes the battles quick and bloody.

item.name: The BoardGameGeek Game
item.comment:
A light set collecting game.
There are 6 turns in the game, and in the first 5 your warehouse receives a stack of your company's game to distribute to different stores.
Next, some or all of your games may be distributed to one of the six stores (players decide in turn order, placing 1 face down counter in the appropriate store - each store only accepts a certain range of games) After all players have passed, play moves to the next phase.
Next, each player rolls 3 dice, which are used to represent buyers. The pips determine at which store these buyers will go.
Following this, each player may spend 1 gg to move one of his die to an adjacent store, or reroll 1 die. After all players have passed, play moves to the next phase.
Flip all face down tiles, then player with the lowest die/dice total goes first, by placing one of his die on a game in the store the die is located at.
Once all die are placed, players receive (for free) the games they have selected, while GG is given to the player selling the game. Essentially you are giving points to the other player, but at no cost to you.
After the 6th round, players tally up their bonus score. For each set of tiles they have collected of a given number (set = 1 copy of each game in the numbered series). Points = number of tiles in the set x 6 (duplicates are worth nothing).
Non-set tiles are worth the number (1-6) listed on them.

item.name: Bohnanza
item.conditiontext: MINT - in original shrink wrap RGG (English) 2000 edition

item.name: Bolide
item.comment: The vector mechanic is relatively easy to use, and may be somewhat difficult to visualize for the first few games, but it works well! No more looking for dice or counting how many squares you need to move to make it into the curve. Luck factor has been eliminated.I did notice a few problems though. First, it can take over an hour to go around the track once, especially with more players.Second, the 'breaking' rule is absurd. A player can pass everyone else at FULL speed (7 in our game) entering a hairpin turn (!?), apply the breaks, and be out of the curve the next turn. For the rest of the players who slowed down, it will take them three turns to negotiate the turn... Dropped the rating to 4.

item.name: Boomtown
item.comment:
An interesting bidding game, where one tries to win the bid in order to have first pick of available Mining operations and/or cards (Dynamite, Saloon, etc.).
High bid passes the amount he/she bid to the player on his/her right. Receiving player takes Â½ and passes to his/her right, etc.
Then bid winner picks first, followed by the player to his left (clockwise order).
First player to gain a pair of Mines in a color becomes the "Mayor" of that City (color). Anytime someone picks up a mine, he/she must pay the Mayor of that City (color) $1 per card the Mayor holds in that color.
Makes for an interesting bidding game, where players try to maximize their selection based on the amount of $ their selecting or not selecting a card will bring them.
This is followed by a 2d6 roll, the total indicating which mines produce (similar to Settlers of Catan).
Then you repeat the process until the deck of cards runs out. Players attempt to take over the Mayor-ship of the various Cities (colors) by having 1 more card of that color.
Points are awarded for each $ + 1 point for each Mine's production capacity + 5 points for each Mayor the player controls.

item.name: Bridge Troll
item.comment: Not my type of game. Too much randomness, not enough control. Even when you win a bid you end up loosing... Definitely not for me.

item.name: Britannia
item.comment: Rather long and repetitive, although it gives a good feel as to the formation of England, thru multiple waves of invasions.
item.conditiontext: In original shrink wrap

item.name: Burg-Ritter
item.comment: Light dexterity game which can be as enjoyable to adults as it is to children.

item.name: The Business Game
item.comment:
Relatively easy to learn game. Your objective is to make a $1M by transporting and selling your resources to North America. Your mine is located in England, where the money used is the Pound. The US$ acts as victory points as it is not interchangeable with the Pound.
To win, one must control the means of transportation, which includes Lorries (trucks), Ferries and Boats (trans-atlantic). Using only one section of the mounted board makes for a good 3-player game. The event cards add just about the right amount of uncertainty. The good card ratio is about 1:3, while the bad cards are 2:3.
Played a 6 player game on Nov.16/2006, and 4 players did not like the game that much. Then again we played for over 3 hours and had just started selling resources to N.America... One player was played with bad luck/bad cards, as he would keep loosing his resources and/or his trucks would be hit by landslides or strikes. He was not a happy camper.

item.name: The Business Game
item.comment:
This is a pickup and deliver type game, where your mine produces ore, which you then need to transport to the warehouse (via truck or ferry), sell for Pounds Sterling, or transport to the US (via ferry or Boat) for US $$. The currencies are NOT interchangeable! First player to $1,000,000 US wins!
There is a fair bit of luck, as production is random, in that your mine will generate resources only if you roll a "6" (I think). Your movement is also random, as you roll 1d6 for movement each turn, although you may spread the pips to any and all of your transporters.
Following this, you may rent three modes of transportation. From the mine to the Warehouse you have the option of a Lorry (capacity = 2) (a.k.a. a truck) for 5 pounds, or a Ferry (capacity = 10), which costs you a certain amount per turn. Extra space on the ferry may be rented to your opponents, for a fixed amount.
Once at the warehouse, you may sell your resources for 20,000 pounds each (IIRC), while the same resource is only worth 5,000 pounds at the mine.
From the Warehouse to the USA, you may rent either a Ferry (10) or a Ship (10). The ship rental fee is higher, but it's route is shorter and it goes to NYC, which offers the best value for the resources. The ferry allows you to chose between NYC or another port which is about half-way distance wise, but offers less per unit.

item.name: Ca$h 'n Gun$
item.comment:
The base game plays quickly as players chose one of their "ammo" cards (you start with 8, three of which are "loaded"), then simultaneously choose their target by pointing their guns, followed by the "Italian word" phase where players either decide to chicken out (lower then character card) or prononce the Italian word and stay up hoping anyone targetting him/her does not have a loaded gun.
After resolving the firing phase ("Bang, Bang, Bang" going first followed by the "Bang" cards), players still standing up divvy up the loot (only equal portions are taken, any remainder is left for the next round). At the end of the 8th round, players add their loot, removing $5K per "Chicken" counter.
BTW, when someone gets shot 3 times he/she is out of the game, so sometimes it is best to duck and take the chicken counter.
The game is Ok to play, especially if players add in a bit of role playing. Unfortunately, I find the price tag for this one to be way too high for a deck of cards, 6 rubber guns and a handful of counters. Still a game I am willing to play if someone else has picked it up.
Playing with the first expansion adds a bit more spice, without complicating the game, nor slowing it. Recommended.

item.name: Call of Cthulhu: The Card Game
Camelot Legends
item.comment: There are a lot of attributes to keep track of. Do start with the basic cards first, not all of them, else you may be overwhelmed.

item.name: Can't Stop
item.comment: A dice game where one needs to decide when to stop. Not really my cup of tea as the dice Gods are seldomly on my side ;)

item.name: Canvas Eagles
item.comment:
Tactical WWI Air Combat game. System is 90% Blue Max, 10% enhancements, which includes altitude. Rules are freely available off several web sites.
Easy to learn and fast playing (simultaneous moves).
1-player per plane.
Game can be played using counters, but looks much better with 1/72nd scale model planes mounted on an antena stand (see photo gallery) especially when on fire or smoking!!
All maneuvers available to your plane are listed graphically, so you can visualize where your plane will be at the end of the turn, as well as which facing it will have. Since movement is simultaneous, you need to estimate where your target will go, and try to get your plane into firing position!
Hosted CE games for the Ottawa Canvas Eagles Group from 2001 to 2004.
In order to enhance our campaign game, I created, in 2003, an Operational Level Campaign System, which was used to port all tactical combat to the CE table. Planes, pilots, location, formation and surprise provided an added level of excitement in our games.

item.name: Carambouille
item.comment: Really not my type of game. Very light, and one has next to no control. Was unable to trade for 4 out of 6 rounds (5-players). Perhaps too much luck involved in the card draw. The special cards don't help either, as other players can really mess you up with those. Could not be tempted to play this again.

item.name: Carcassonne
item.comment:
This is a very light puzzle type game, where you draw a tile and place it on the board, possibly adding a meeple to score some points.
The expansions probably add more fun to it, but I prefer meatier games.

item.name: Carrom
item.comment: One of those family games that is short, easy to teach and fun to play. Not to mention that it should be fairly easy to build your own board/set!

item.name: Carson City
item.comment:
This is NOT a brain burner, and could easily be accessible to the entire family. It may be a little long to explain initially, perhaps due to the impact each Building/House placement has on the value of adjacent Buildings.
This impact makes the game quite interesting, as the denser the town's core, the more expensive it is to buy land at that location! At the same time, it's a great spot for the placement of a Bank or Saloon!
The forced placement of houses whenever buildings are placed (except for Mines and Ranches), makes this system work quite nicely.
"Role selection" is fairly straight forward, as the character you select will give you a bonus of some sort, but will also limit the amount of cash you may carry over from turn to turn...
One of the finer aspects of this game is that you are never out of the running, there is always a different approach or strategy you can use! Multiple combos are open to you (Saloon/Hotel, Drugstore/Ranches, Bank/Mines, etc), and you'll also find spaces to generate income should you be short.
The "road" approach (actions are conducted one space at a time along the "road") makes for easy turn resolution, and each space is placed intelligently! For example, buying land occurs before you may purchase buildings, and income only comes AFTER these buying phases, so you better have kept some money from the previous turn. But wait, after income you may purchase the all important points! What to do, what to do?!
And I almost forgot, there are also "Show downs" a.k.a duels, as only ONE player may perform each action (except for 2 which may be performed by multiple players), so if more than one player placed a cowboy at a location, the duel is conducted by a single die roll (adding your "fire power" rating as a bonus). The winner may conduct the action, the looser(s) receive their cowboy, which may be used at a later turn, and which immediately provides you with a "fire power" bonus.
Ohh, and there are only four turns...
There is one thing I really dislike, and it's the fact that very few points are scored in the few 2-3 rounds, so you end up with a large amount of points scored in the last round... Makes for a rather un-rewarding ending.

item.name: Castle
item.comment: One play. Some of the mechanics are interesting, but I'm not really into this type of game.

item.name: Castle Dice
item.comment:
Interesting resource sharing mechanic.
Some cards unbalance the game, especially when they are drawn by the same 1-2 players...
Advantage seems to go to player who plays 1st, therefore horses are important to get... as are all the other resources. A euro with dice (random resource production, which is then pooled, then picked from in turn order. :)

item.name: Catan
item.comment:
For a Euro type game, there is luck involved. Although the trade mechanic is fun, it really is all about selecting the best location to establish your towns/cities.
If your numbers don't come up often, then you will quickly fall behind. Initial placement, luck of the die and cards make a very large difference at the start of the game, but can be compensated via inter-player trade.

item.name: Cave Troll
item.comment:
Played a 2-player game... when does the fun start?
Probably better with 4, but pointless as a two player game.

item.name: Caylus
item.comment:
Easy to play but not so easy to master.
Everything you need to know about the game is right on the board or on the tiles, so there is little need for player aids (although newbies should use them).
You will always have more things you'd like to do than you have resources, so resource management is the key to everything.
The money (denier) coins are too thin/small and should be replaced by poker chips.
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Chaos in the Old World
item.comment: Played blue and did not enjoy the game whatsoever. Did not appear to have any control, nor could I defend against red, who seems to harass me and wipe out all my Cultists on every turn... Ended up advancing the wheel twice and scoring 14 points....

item.name: Chess
item.comment: The grand father of all war games. This one has been analyzed to death, and probably requires a lifetime to master. My rating peaked at 1750, IIRC.

item.name: Chinatown
item.comment: Fairly straight forward, easy to learn. Speculation and trade (between players). Randomness is somewhat alleviated by the fact that you receive 2 more cards then you keep, thus selecting the ones you want, and you can always trade/exchange businesses (tokens) and lots with the other players.

item.name: Citadels
item.comment: Good game with 4 or more players. NOT recommended with 3 players as the Thieve's role is next to useless as the other players can ofteb spend all their gold with one of their character's, thus leaving nothing for the Thief at the start of the target role's turn.

item.name: Clash of Cultures
item.comment:
An excellent CIV game.
If we could rate the designer, Christian Marcussen would be in my top 3 list. Also enjoy his [gameid=25292].
The game flows fairly well, but you will need to play a few turns in order to understand the intricacies of this one. The tech tree has built in prerequisites which do not require a complex tree/branch diagram. Really like the simplicity of the solution offered here.
Gives a good feel of a CIV game, and the simplicity of the combat allows you to focus on the CIV side, not war (although there are more than enough tech options, adding pips and dividing by 5, as in [gameid=232], keeps things moving).
The Event Deck, which triggers the Barbarians, adds enough uncertainty in the beginning turns.
The Objective cards, which are dual-use (Development at the top, Military at the bottom) is again a simple and elegant solution, giving players some flexibility.
Some nasty events give you VP, which allows you to stay in the running for total VP.
One player had some issues with the movement rules, specifically when an army moves in a mountain (no more moves this turn) or through a forest (may move again, but cannot combat). Although this rule may appear gamey, the ROADS tech gives you some flexibility here (but your surprise attack will cost you some resources).
My new favorite CIV game! Looking forward to playing it again.

item.name: Cleopatra and the Society of Architects
item.comment: The pieces look great! I was unable to see the game in here though, and player interaction is essentially non-existant.
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Cockroach Poker
item.comment: Pure bluffing game, with eight "suits" (bugs), each with eight cards. The first player to accumulate 3 or 4 cards of the same type (depending on # of players), or to run out of cards, looses, everyone else wins.

item.name: Code Name: Sector
item.comment: This game is more interesting when using the advanced rules, which limit ship movement (dependant on type of ship you are commanding). Can be played solo, which is great!

item.name: Cold War
item.comment: An interesting power politic game. Rather bland for my tastes.

item.name: Coloretto
item.comment: Average game where one needs to build colored sets. A tad bland for me.

item.name: Colosseum
item.comment:
Gorgeous looking game, with the usual high quality components we have come to expect from Days of Wonder. Unfortunately, the lamest DoW game I have seen to date. The game rules are geared towards rewarding the last place player, by having them steal a token from the leader... Game Leader auto-bashing?
In the last game I played, I lead the first four (out of five) rounds, only to finish dead last, a good 10 points from 3rd place... Interestingly, I went out of my way to not finish in first place on one round, but still did... My friends recall this game by the Janis "show", where I was only able to produce a horse, out of the four tiles needed for the show, yet I still managed to remain in first place. LOL!
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, near mint. Has been played a few (3) times.

item.name: Commands & Colors: Ancients
item.comment: Memoir 44 advanced. The Commander adds a lot to the game, and I love those line moves! Unfortunately I need to remember that Cavalry should be kept in reserve, and used to eliminate a weak unit. The Infantry was the Queen of the battlefield back then, and it is well modeled in this game!
item.conditiontext: Excellent - Played a few times, thus saves you the 4-5 hours of sticking on the labels! PREFER to trade with expansions #1, #2 and #3 (what would I do with the expansions and no base game?)

item.name: Concordia
item.comment:
Nice components. Like the actions being limited by cards in hand. Diplomat is very strategic.
Really like the Provincial production and the coin collecting to reset the Provincial production. Wished the Provinces included more than 2-3 Cities...
Players were going for easy (ie. solo) builds in a 3-player game. Will need to try same number on Italia map as it is tighter.

item.name: Conquest
item.comment:
An interesting Chess like system, with a lot of possible combinations. Recommend the puzzle books if you would like to learn the finer elements of the game/system.
2-player and 4-player versions available (different boards). Nice pieces which can lock together (Soldier & Elephant, Soldier & Chariot, etc.)
Area movement where each side has 20 moves per turn. If you capture an opponent's piece, he/she immediately gets 2 moves to respond, unless it was your last action.

item.name: Conquest of the Empire
item.comment:
Tried the advanced game and really did not like it. Perhaps we are playing this wrong, but with armies being able to move all over the place in a single move, who needs navies? No fun factor here.
The base game is an adaptation of RISK.
On the positive side, the board and components are nice, as are the cards for CotEII.
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Conquest of the Fallen Lands
item.conditiontext: Near mint - Game has been opened

item.name: Constantinopolis
item.comment:
Player boards reminds me of PUERTO RICO, actual game play reminds me of SAINT PETERSBURG, as one needs to develop one's economy before switching to making points.
Yet, ship deliveries are a good way of making much needed cash, and a few points as well.
Game may suffer from a run away leader problem.
Player interaction is limited to the bidding for the different Offices (i.e. turn order) as well as the available Production/Commerce/Special tiles.

item.name: Container
item.comment: An interesting approach to a semi-closed economic game. You have no direct control over anything other then the price you set for your goods, and what you need to do is entice the other players to pickup and deliver the goods you need on the center island. Hopefully you will have the cash necessary to bid for their delivery.The components are generally nice, and I especially like the size of the ships. The color of the ships are so so at best (they can be painted over), and the game cannot be played by color blind people (some colors are difficult to differentiate for those of us who are NOT color blind!)With only two actions to perform when it is your turn to play, downtime appears to be minimal.

item.name: Coup: The Resistance Universe
item.comment:
Only one play, with 3 players.
Game was over in about 5 minutes (3 rounds), with the explanation of how the assassin works, when it took out a play in a single shot... Not all that good with 3 players, but willing to give it another go with 5 or 6.

item.name: Coyote
item.comment: Light party game. Played with six, was interesting. May be boring if you are the first player eliminated, but plays quickly enough, so you'll only be out of the game for 5 to 10 minutes.

item.name: Crazy Kick
item.comment:
Quick, loud game of card-soccer! Play is quite fast, so fast that some cards will get folded in the fray!
Games last 5 to 10 minutes, and is good party game fillers!

item.name: Cribbage
item.comment: Team play is best for me.

item.name: Crimson Skies
item.comment: Simplistic but fast playing 2D aerial combat game. The movement system is rather interesting as player lay down octogons as per the pattern on their maneuver card to find out where their plane will end its movement. Firing and damage is straight forward, and damage is applies by clicking the target plane's base, thus reducing its capabilities. Also comes with a bar brawl sub game. Anyone who has played a WizKids type game before should have no problems stepping into this one. But don't expect a realistic battle, as the game is set in the "Crimson Skies" alternate universe. It is still enjoyable, and a game can be played in under 30 minutes.

item.name: Crude: The Oil Game
item.comment:
A pure speculation game. I like the fact that this game is relatively simple, so no brain burning required except when a news event triggers a tax/fees, then the calculator has to come out.
Very nice components (Stronghold Games edition).
This is a 4-player game, with rules for 3 and 2 players, but it still plays like a 4 player game (with a dummy @ 3 players, and each player controlling 2 zones @ 2 players).

item.name: Crusader Rex
item.comment:
Two plays in (still learning the game)
Good game on the Third Crusade. It is fairly quick to play (3-4 hours) and the mechanics work well, IMHO. Every turn there are some though decisions to be made, from deciding to consolidate, muster, launch an attack, reinforce a City or try to lift a siege.
The combat system is similar to the one found in WIZARD KINGS and to some extent VICTORY!, but one has more options such as 'Charge' for Crusader units, 'Harry' for Saracens and Turcopoles. Not to mention 'Storm Castle' and 'Sally' to meet the besieging forces on the field.
The beauty of the system is the limited resources you have, represented by the cards. Therefore you need to have a general idea of what you'd like to do during each of the 6 game years, while retaining some flexibility in order to counter your opponents moves.
If you're interested in this period, I recommend you read THOMAS F. MADDEN's review here on BGG, as well as his book, [b][i]The New Concise History of the Crusades[/i][/b], which gives a good overview of the period. [u]ISBN[/u]: 0-7425-3822-2 (hardcover)

item.name: Cuba
item.comment:
I enjoyed this title, which appears to be a well balanced mix of mechanics from other games. Each player has the same 5 "roles", of which he/she will play 4, the 5th being used for the voting phase of the game.
One of the "roles" collects resources/produce for the player. Another role allows for the building/purchase of building tiles, similar to Caylus. Players score points when they deliver goods to the boats at the dock (value of delivery increases the longer the board stays in port).
The 5th "role", which was not played, now acts as the number of votes the player has for the Political Phase, where 2 out of 4 new laws are selected by the winner of the vote "bid" (pesos can be added to bonify your "offer").
All in all, good game length, clear mechanic, has multiple paths to victory (via tile combos, different strategies, etc.). IMHO, way ahead of PR.

item.name: Cyclades
item.comment:
The version we played had wooden pieces... Our 5-player game dragged and was longer than 3 hours. Players would bid and overbid, in an attempt to block one another. I was able to build my first metropolis on the last turn of the game... Was able to get Ares (God of War) once during the game... Mythological creatures unbalances what could have been a balanced game... The player with the most money has an advantage that appears difficult to overcome.
After a second game (4-players this time), found it to be too dependent on luck (die rolls in combat, card draw for creatures, as well as the Gods when played with less than 5 players). And it dragged, again, over 2.5 hours... If one player plays badly, it really skews the game, and then there is the dreaded King Maker moves... After 2.5 hours, really??
Not recommended.

item.name: Darjeeling
item.comment: Relatively easy and fast playing game. Interesting mechanic to determine the value of a delivery, which simulates demand (following a delivery, the demand is lower, therefore so is the selling price).

item.name: Darkest Night
item.comment:
Game play is fairly straightforward, winning will require some planning, and a bit of luck (combat requires a success on a die, and is similar to [gameid=15987]).
Very nicely produced components! (laser cutting does leave a bit of sooth)
Cards are of good quality (size: standard M:TG)
Love the board, as it lies flat. It does require minor assembly (4 puzzle pieces).
Rulebook: Full color!
As with most games, requires one play through in order to grasp all the mecanics. We had to remind players to draw an Event card when they were not at the Monastery. Had to look up some rules, as players did not understand that you can only remove a blight when you are the one attacking it (your Action). Further, there are two sets of numbers on each blight. One if when you attack it on your turn, the other, on the back, is when it forces you to attack/defend (those numbers are usually lower).
Edit: 3 plays in with 3-Players, 4-Players and 2-Players, and this is a winner for me. Already ordered the expansion, and looking forward to trying out the 4 new characters!

item.name: Darkest Night: With an Inner Light
Dealer's Choice
item.comment: French name: AUTO BROCANTE

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark
item.comment:
DOOM in the RUNEBOUND universe. It is an interesting tactical combat game in an adventure setting. The game can take some time to complete (4 - 6 hours) and I don't particularly like the GM drawing cards and "preparing" traps for you by spawning in front and behind your party. Like DOOM, in that you need to keep pressing forward, else you'll loose.
I would have prefered some sort of event deck which gets triggered randomly, and where all players are playing together.

item.name: Descent: Journeys in the Dark (Second Edition)
Diabolo
item.comment: Played only once with 5-players. Had next to no control and appears to be luck driven. Game is most likely better with 3 or 4 players, as they may have a bit more control.

item.name: Diamant
item.comment: A light game which can be fun when played with the right group. The SCHMIDT SPIELE's version has better looking diamonds then FunAgain's opaque plastic (they have the shape of a tooth)

item.name: Dicke Kartoffeln
item.comment: A speculation game, where finances are very tight. Crop rotation is necessary, and those worms are critical to your operation!

item.name: Domaine
item.comment: Only played once. Not really into this type of game.

item.name: Dominion
item.conditiontext:
First Edition Like new - played a few times (cards were initially sleeved)
Would prefer to trade as a bundle with Dominion INTRIGUE and Dominion SEASIDE (both are new, still in shrink wrapping)

item.name: Doom: The Boardgame
item.comment:
Rating dropped from 6 to 4. After a few more plays with 3 marines, it has become obvious this game is unbalanced. Although the monsters scale up with the number of players, the ammunition does not so you are sharing whatever is on that level with the extra players. Perhaps it works better with 1 or 2 marines? With a full complement of (3) marine players, the object is not really to fight, but to run to the exit.
For what it is, the game it too long. The interlocking "map" pieces are nice, so are most of the plastic minis. The larger monsters have a warped base.
Another issue is with the writing on the special dice, which wears off after about 12 games.

item.name: Draco & Co
item.comment: A light card game where you try to gain the most gold/silver by moving your two characters closer/away from Draco. You have next to no control in this one, and there is not much of a game here either, as the fun seems to be missing. Yet I'm sure we took all the items out of the box!?

item.name: Duel of Ages Set 1: Worldspanner
item.comment:
Very good concept, but flawed execution. Everyone starts "naked", and you need lady luck on your side in order to "pass" those labyrinth challenges, which will provide you with weapons, armor, transportation or the likes. It would be more interesting as a squad based combat system, IMO, with both sides starting with weapons.
Cards are nice, but the all important boards are not flat. Requires the use of a sheet of plexiglas.

item.name: Dune
item.comment:
Played two 6-player games, both with the Fremen, and was utterly unimpressed.
I had never seen a more unbalanced game, where some players are spectators more than anything else (especially the Freman).
This is a game where the stong will go out of their way to take out the weak, because the winner gets rewarded in spice (the game's currency) for taking out leaders, theirs included. Unfortunately, that makes the weak a prime target, and they only get weaker, not to say taken out of the "game", if it can be called that.
By pure luck (4 worm signs out of 5 cards), and multiple alliance changes in a row, the Fremen are now somehow in a position to win a battle... Unfortunately, they don't have any leaders.
In my two games, my impression was that I had no control whatsoever. It is a diplomatic game more than anything else, but since the Fremen have nothing of value to offer, it is very difficult to enter into an alliance, let alone collect any spice which may help them get out of this predicament. Does this sound like a solid "10" game?
To add insult to injury, the Atreides sells info to the B.G., letting that player know which cards you purchased...
Based on my experiences, I am unable to see where's the enjoyment. Surely these players don't play with the Fremen! An utterly pointless game, yet I was wiling to give this one another try, as so many folks here appear to enjoy this game (for the life of me, I can't understand why).
Merits a 1, but the game oozes with theme, so it earns a 2 (most pointless 4 hour non-game I have ever seen).

item.name: Dungeons & Dragons Miniatures
item.comment: The combat system is not all that new... Still interesting. The collectible aspect kills it for me though.

item.name: The Dutch Golden Age
item.comment:
A light-medium game, with some randomness. As can be expected from Phalanx, the board is nice, as are the components.
Fairly easy to learn and quick to play. Rules translations is OK, although some points are not clear, and there are a few word transpositions...
In the setup for example, one places 1 Influence marker (cardboard token) and two Movement tokens (wooden cylinder). They why it is described in the manual, it would seem they have this reversed, as they list the number of each token remaining, which are the totals for the OTHER pieces. After setup, you should have the following remaining (unless I interpretted things wrong):
3 Movement tokens 5 Influence markers

item.name: DVONN
item.comment:
Not really a fan of shrinking playing area... Kind of a combo of checkers and [thing=528][/thing], except the stacks must move as many spaces are there are tokens in it. Token on top of the stack denotes the owning player. Player with the most tokens at the end of the game (when no more moves are possible) wins.
Prefer [thing=7854][/thing] in this series.

item.name: Ebbe & Flut
item.comment: There is some depth to this one, as the card movement mechanic is interesting. Rules are easy to learn, but the game requires a few session to really get a hold as to which moves are better. Game can be played solo.

item.name: Eclipse
item.comment: Best game design I have seen in a very long time. Can't find any flaws after several plays. Painless accounting allows you to concentrate on the game. Next to no downtime, plays relatively fast for a 4X game! Best of class!

item.name: Edo
item.comment:
A good Euro. You only have 3 actions each turn, although some you can do more than once if you have the Agents/Samurai needed (sometimes both).
You start with 3 action cards, each one with 4 possible actions. Problem is there is always one on which you'd like to do two actions, but you can only select one...
Makes for some tough decisions.
Trade is key, IMHO.
We had a player who never feed her Samurai until the last turn... She finished 2nd. So instead of spending an action collecting rice, she spent it sending Samurais on the board and moving them. Interesting action management.
Collecting resources can be iffy, as the more Samurai in that location, the less resources you collect.
Points are made when building (House-1, Trading Post-2, Fortress-3, and trading). Income is generated in each city when you have a House or your Trading Post, and is affected by the number of players with buildings in that location (ie. area majority).

item.name: Egizia
item.comment:
This one appears to be a light worker placement and resource management game. After a few plays, one quickly finds out that it's a tad heavier than that. Randomness is very limited (Sphinx cards), but may be mitigated by utilizing more resources to draw more cards (up to 5, may keep 1, rest are converted to victory points).
One side of the Nile has market and worker upgrades, as well as 3 building sites. The other side has bonus cards, which you can collect by placing one of your ships (workers) there.
After the placement of ships along the Nile, players must feed their workers (based on their total strength), pays in VP any food shortages. The Nile has three water levels; the better fields always produce, while the other two types are dependent on the water's level. This simple mechanic provides enough incentive to increase food output at the same time as one increases his/her work force.
Next, all queries produce stones, which you will need at the three building sites, assuming you were able to place a ship there (there are only 3 spots at each, with the possibility of a forth, if someone is unable to build).
Following this, players receive bonus points based on cooperation at the building sites. Essentially, you get 1/3/6 bonus points depending on how many sites you worked on.
Each construction provides 1 VP per stone/worker required. To place 1 stone, 1 worker is required, so having a larger work force then you have stones is only going to end up costing you more food. You need to use a balanced approach when it comes to Stones, Food and Workers.
Each building of the three building sites requires/provides different bonuses:
- Sphinx (you can purchase up to 5 cards, may only keep one, the rest are returned to the bottom of the deck, and are converted into an immediate 1 VP bonus. These cards provide end game bonuses (4-10 points), if you have meet the indicated requirement. There is a similar bonus mechanic in AMUN RE). - Tomb/Obelisk (there are building constraints here, and when you build here, you also receive a free upgrade in either the food or stone market) - Pyramid/Temple (similar constraints here, with the pyramid providing extra points for majority in each row. Further, there are numerous Sphinx cards for this area)
All in all, a relatively simple game, which offers some interesting decisions and a multitude of paths to victory (bonus cards, building, etc.).

item.name: Elasund: The First City
item.comment:
An interesting game that has nothing to do with SETTLERS OF CATAN.
The building permit mechanic adds an extra level of strategy, as does the possibility of building over smaller buildings.
There may be some down time during the first game, but that is to be expected with most games. While other players are taking their turns, everyone should be reviewing the board and figuring out their next move(s), or checking out how they can block other players.
The luck factor is limited, and should be viewed more as a bonus, as you can trade the building permit phase for 2 gold.
Each player controls his/her destiny by selecting different actions. Although you'd like to do everything, you are limited in what you can do. Nothing wrong with that, in my books.

item.name: Eldritch Horror
item.comment:
Only played one game. Setup was a little long, and needs to be followed step-by-step. Game play becomes fairly intuitive after a few turns.
It's lighter than ARKHAM HORROR, but it's about the same length. A 3 hour game time is most probably possible if the game is already set up and everyone knows how to play.
Components are of great quality, as we have come to expect from FFG.

item.name: Elk Fest
item.comment:
First off, you don't get much in this one: 8 pieces of wood (2 moose, 2 quai and 6 discs). It's a game you can play on any smooth surface table, including the school's cafeteria.
We should have a "very light" Game Play weight, as this game would fit right in there!

item.name: Empire Builder
item.comment: Nice mechanics are work here, game plays wells. A tad long, but am looking forward to playing this one again.

item.name: Empires in Arms
item.comment: Very detailed Napoleonic war game. Detailed coverage of all aspects, from Diplomacy to Forage. Takes a very long time to play, this is probably best played by e-mail.

item.name: Endeavor
item.comment:
A game of maximizing and balancing your actions.
Easy to learn, intuitive play, nice components, and clean mechanic which works well with the theme. Especially like the way labor payments are handled!
Excellent replay value as tokens are redistributed every game.
NOT language specific. Only the rules are required, and the names on the board and buildings if you really want to.
Played 5-player and 3-player games. With more players are choices are fewer and it is more difficult to plan between turns, but you still have multiple choices and may still adapt your play.
Can be somewhat difficult to determine who's in the lead, until you've played a few games.
All information is on the table, so game will be slower with AP players...

item.name: Escape: The Curse of the Temple
item.comment:
A great little coop game, which takes no more than 10 minutes to play.
Only 6 pages of rules. Initially used ALL the tiles, then figured out there was a basic set as well as a Treasure and Curses set... And most importantly, there are 13 tiles to a set, PLUS 4 tiles with multiple gem locations.
Components are great for what they are.
Everyone enjoyed their first experience... so much so we played 8 games in a row, in just about 90 minutes.

item.name: EVE: The Second Genesis
item.comment: Only one play using the AMARR and MINMATAR starter decks. Found it rather unbalanced in favor of te Minmatar, as my ships were fairly quickly disposed of by my opponent, as all I seem to have were mining ships... Of course this requires more plays, but we will most probably be using the other starters to see if it is more balanced.

item.name: Fairy Tale
item.comment: Only played once with 5-players and don't see why I would want to give this another try. The card draft mechanic is the only thing I found to be Ok, but I played with experienced players and had no idea what I was looking for (which combinations to try and get). My opponents obviously had no problems blocking whatever it is I was trying to do, while both left and right opponents are the ones who scored the most (obviously I was not blocking them). Definitely not for me.

item.name: Felix: The Cat in the Sack
item.comment:
A different twist to a bidding game. Players all place one of their cards face down, and 1 card is revealed until one player opts to pass, at which time s/he picks up the tokens from the 2nd column (a passing bonus if you will) and reveals the second card. All players who did not pass may bid, the next player to pass takes the money from the 3rd column, etc. Placing the last card provides you with a slight advantage as you know what that card is, and may therefore know the total # of points this hand will yield once the next to last card is revealed, making bluffing a distinct possibility.
The total may be negative, although some of the 'bad' cards cancel each other out if there is a pair of them on the table.

item.name: Fire & Axe: A Viking Saga
item.comment:
The AsmodÃ©e edition has very nice bits and a good looking board. Somehow, the "Fury" must have been lost in translation as combat is minimal. Even though I suck at die rolling, I prefer more combat than what is offered here (which is mostly Trade and Settlements).
Being able to do 7 actions all at once is good, but while the other players are taking their turn there is very little for you to do. With the downtime, I was able to plan my next turn while my opponents were doing theirs, then still had time to kill, therefore making this game a tad boring for me.

item.name: Flash Point: Fire Rescue
item.comment:
Relatively easy to play/learn coop game, but not so easy to win.
Love the double side board (easy / difficult) and the components are excellent quality for this type of game.

item.name: Flat Top
item.comment:
An excellent Operational Level simulation of Carrier combat! Every turn is ONE hour, and you need to micro manage your forces down to the single PLANE. Capital ships are named.
Don't be frightened by the "High Complexity" rating this game has, since the rules are intuitive.
The mapboard is nice, but the spotting rules are a bit odd. Best played with a GM (i.e. 3-players). Lends itself well to PBeM!! :)

item.name: Fleet Admiral
item.comment:
Rolling the die to see if you even get to do something that turn is a little too chaotic for me, but apart from that, the game is OK.
I like the tongue in cheek reference to Star Trek, but I would have retained the colors! (unless Paramount has reserved the rights for the association of Red with Security? And being killed if you are new to the ship and sent on an away mission?)
The game plays fairly quickly, and the semi-coop aspect on the 2nd mission keeps the other players interested in everyone's action, as they can they offer to "assist", to get first pick at the card reward.
The components are Ok for what the are, and the cards have an acceptable thickness. Only thing is they cannot be sleeve with regular sleeves, and the square ones (for the 2-player game of Catan) are too large :(

item.name: Der Fliegende HollÃ¤nder
item.comment: Was really not impressed by this one, as it tends to degenerate into endless negotiations. I had enough after the 2nd turn.

item.name: Fluxx
item.comment: A light game with a lot of randomness, yet fun to play with the right people. Games can be played in 2-30 minutes. Very limited planning.

item.name: Flying Carpet
item.comment: An OK light filler racing game where one attempts to avoid obstacles and/or land on an opponents piece to send them flying to the ground.

item.name: For Sale
