item.comment: Very easy bidding, plays in 20-30 minutes with 6 players. Excellent filler.

item.name: Formidable Foes
item.comment: Nice components, but I'm not into this type of game. Came across as a light resource management type game, where one needs to maximize his/her move and manage his/her "green discs" (whatever they were called - energy/strenght).
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Formula DÃ©
item.comment: This is a nice, quick playing race game, in which you need to manage your car's speed via gear shifting. Each gear uses a different die; 1st = d4, 2nd = d6, 3rd = d8, 4th = d12, 5th = d20, 6th = d30. Races are 1 to 3 laps, depending on how much time you want to spend, and how complex you want the game to be. Pit stops are possible with 2 and 3 lap races.

item.name: Formula Motor Racing
item.comment:
A quick playing racing game which can be played almost anywhere. It takes about 20-30 minutes per round.
Good component quality, although I had to break apart all the cards as they were all stuck together (packaging?); none where damaged.

item.name: Fresco
item.comment:
A fairly easy game to teach and play. I like the worker/painter secret/simultaneous placement, as it speeds up the game and provides a good "feel" with the theme.
The paint mixing is a nice touch, and also goes to show that one can teach by playing a game!

item.name: Die Fugger
item.comment: Played twice with 2 players. Probably better with more.

item.name: Fullmetal Alchemist: Trading Card Game
item.comment:
A challenging TCG!
The combat mechanic is interesting, especially with more than 2 players!
The game is especially well balanced when there are more than 2 players. Of course, more players means more time to play.
If you enjoy deck building, this one can present some interesting options, depending on the Hero/Vilain you choose.
item.conditiontext: All cards are in plastic sleeves

item.name: Funny Friends
item.comment: Only played once. Can be difficult to catch up when you're the 6th player.

item.name: Fury of Dracula (second edition)
item.comment:
A refreshing coop game, where 4 players try to track down and kill Dracula. The Dracula player has a deck of cards which s/he uses to move secretly about the board, while at the same time setting up encounters/traps for the other players. Dracula's objective is to "mature" vampires and stay alive long enough to accumulate 6 Vampire points. Everyone else tries to prevent this from happening.
The move/action sequence plays really fast, and there is no down time unless there is combat. Once combat starts, it can be somewhat tedious if you don't have the right item(s), so it may be best to run to fight another day. The combat system is "blow-by-blow", which makes it last a little longer, but it's entertaining to watch, initially anyways.
If you like "Mr. X" or "Scotland Yard" type games, this one comes highly recommended.
My copy did have one unfortunate problem; the counter sheet was not punched thoroughly, thus most of the encounter tokens where damaged when we tried to punch them out. We even tried using an xacto, but that didn't help. :(
I wrote to FFG and they promptly sent me a replacement flat! Excellent customer service!!

item.name: Galactic Emperor
item.comment:
Rating after a 6-player game. The game is a very light version of Twilight Imperium, but still takes a long time to play with 6 players. After the game a few of us discussed the possibility of trying it again, but with only 4 players.
In order to win one has to score the most victory points (VP chits are the only hidden info), and VP are accumulated via the control of planets (1 VP/planet) as well as the destruction/removal of the last "influence" token (i.e. control marker) of an opponent (1 VP).
The Regent phase, where the VPs are scored and where it is possible to place 2-3 Influence/Control markers, allows players to reduce someone else's control of a system, or even take control without firing a shot. Although cheaper than building ships, it can give you the edge, until you can reinforce with the navy.
Our 6-player game ended with the following scores: 29, 26, 21, 14, 14 and 12. My impression was that the person with 26 points would win, but another player's last play was to not attack the leaders, thus allowing them to retain their planets/points as well as score 2 easy points, else it would have been tighter for 1st place.

item.name: Galaxy Defenders
item.comment:
Reminds me of X-COM: UFO DEFENSE. Nice game components, and a clean mechanics. The campaign game is good.
Games can drag/be too long, and there is something which doesn't jive with the dice combat system. Too often 4 or 5 hits are scored, only to be ALL blocked by the defense, which has a 30% chance per die. If this is bad luck, it can really scrap what was, up to that point, a good game.
Unfortunately, this game will not hit the table as often as it should as one member of my game group finds it too long... time to find new players ;)

item.name: Galaxy Trucker
item.comment:
A light/funny game which combines a few elements: tile laying (when building your ship), light racing game (when going thru the "adventure deck") and resource collecting/management (energy and cargo).
Although it may be played by the entire family, there is nothing anyone can do to prevent an experienced player from winning, not to mention that the element of luck is rampant.
In the last game I have played, the experienced player never had more than ONE empty square on his ship! In the third race, he had a laser in EVERY column, and only one empty square still... It becomes extremely difficult to get the proper tiles as everyone draws from the same pool, so there is a large element of luck during the draw, as sometimes you will get a good piece you can't use, and of course someone else will grab it. The experienced players will know which pieces NOT to return to the center.
Best (fun) played versus players of the same level.

item.name: Galaxy: The Dark Ages
item.conditiontext: Excellent condition, played once.

item.name: A Game of Thrones (first edition)
item.comment: Very interesting diceless game. I like the mix with "Diplomacy" where units may provide support, and the added flexibility of the combat House cards.The randomness of some of the events increases the game's replyability.
item.conditiontext: Unpunched copy signed (on box cover) by Christian T. Petersen. Will only trade as a set with both expansions (A Clash of Kings + A Storm of Swords)

item.name: Giganten
item.comment:
Speculation game, fairly well balanced. No one is out of the race until the money is counted at the end.
Easy to learn, fairly quick to play. Expect some tough decisions along the way! The Production Certificates and bidding are quite important.
Players cannot be blocked, but you can slow them down.
Excellent mechanic of increased costs due to expanding infrastructure, but having a card which moves every other player's train backwards 3 to 5 spaces, regardless of cost. Allows trailing players to catch up too.
Production quality is EXCELLENT!!
item.conditiontext: Game components in excellent condition. Box has a taped corner, but overall in excellent condition.

item.name: Gloria Mundi
item.comment:
In our first game, we had missed the following very important setup instruction: "[i]"Each player places one of his production cards of each type, face up, in his play area in front of his screen".[/i]".
Tried it a second time and something just does not feel right, as it is too easy to take out a good building from your neighbor to the left (i.e. next player), and there is nothing he/she can do to prevent it, nor can he/she attack you back. I really PO'ed my neighbor to the left as I only had (3) farms, and he would loose a City or Legion whenever it was my turn as I could seldom pay the tribute.
[u]Positive[/u]: The mounted board is nice, and I really like the cards. The purchasing and production mechanics are good, especially the combos that can be had.
[u]Negative[/u]: The box should have been smaller, and the board, although nice, could have been just a straight line (although it looks good, it serves no purpose other than as a component place holder and a race track). The wooden blocks are too small.
item.conditiontext: Game is in Excellent condition (near mint), only played twice. Complete.

item.name: Glory to Rome
item.comment:
A lot of difficult choices to make, as you may use a card in multiple ways.
As per the suggestion in the rules, play your first game without using the abilities conferred by the buildings, so you may grasp the "flow". In my first game I had a hard time selecting between Architect and Craftsman, as one allows you to play a card from your hand while the other is from the stockpile.
Definitely worth a few more tries as there are a lot of possible combos!

item.name: Goa
item.comment:
Game of Action maximization/management. Essentially everyone is using resources (Spice, Ships and Colonists) to upgrade different aspect of his/her company, or colonize the four islands. It is mostly a game of upgrades, where everything is intertwined.
Player interaction limited to the auction phase, and the board serves little purpose other than as a place holder for the cards...
Still, it can be an enjoyable experience with the right crowd.

item.name: Guatemala CafÃ©
item.comment:
Once you get past the badly written/organized rules, there is a good game in there. A paragraph laying out the Turn Sequence and options available would have helped.
There are labels to apply (35), but this is fairly fast, especially if you've done this for several hours with games such as [gameid=14015] and/or [gameid=87].
Play is fairly straightforward, and blocking other players is possible (on the Plantation board). Apart from that, there is not much player interaction. The player to your right may be able to limit your options depending on how he/she moves the "Buyer" piece (on the Production/Purchase board).
If using the blockading rules for scoring, the game may appear pointless as it is possible that no points get scored until three quarters of the game has been played. Yet, blockading is not that bad of a rule once you've played the game a few times.
item.conditiontext: Mint, in original shrink-wrapping.

item.name: Guesstures
item.comment: This is a light "party" game. It is always fun to see the other players try to act out their cards, but it may be difficult to do so yourself! Each turn, a player draws 4 cards, decides which portion of the card (top or bottom) he/she would like to do (each section is worth different points, usually 1 for the top and 3 for the bottom (blue cards), or 2 for the top and 4 for the bottom (red cards). The player then places the cards in the order he/she wishes, on top of the director's board, then starts the timer. If your team is not fast enough to call out the proper word, the card drops into the device and you can't score points for it. On the other hand, if the word is guessed, then the player needs to remove the card ASAP, before it drops, else no points are scored.

item.name: Guillotine
item.comment:
Was not impressed during my first game, but still picked up a copy in a Math-Trade. I am not disappointed, as it is a light filler which is quick and easy to play. There are some interesting combos, and it is possible to affect other players with card play.
Do take the time to read the action cards. If the players get into the game, it can be quite funny.
Go a head. ;)

item.name: Gulo Gulo
item.comment: OK, this is a kids game, but it can be enjoyable with the right people at the end of a gaming day. Apart from that, I don't really see myself playing this too often...

item.name: Gunslinger
item.comment: I like the simultaneous action selection mechanic, which each action have a different amount of time required to execute. Theme is good, and one always looks for cover!
item.conditiontext: Near Mint - unpunched. Trade interest: Low (collector's item)

item.name: Hasch mich!
item.comment: Very light game, although I did not find it to be that much fun. It's a reflex game, where one is to react to rolls of 7 and 11, else one's mice might be caught by the cat (plunger in the game I played). Good filler game at a convention though.

item.name: Hats Off
item.comment: It's a light dexterity game, which can be thought in seconds, and plays within a handful of minutes. Not my type of game, but had fun playing this, more because of the good people I was gaming with.

item.name: Le Havre
item.conditiontext: New, still in shrink wrap.

item.name: Hermagor
item.comment: Rating based on two plays. It's all in the placement of those "buyers", and securing the tiles you need in order to establish a trading post in the various cities/towns. A good mix of a few different mechanics.

item.name: Heroes of Graxia
item.comment:
An interesting mix of THUNDERSTONE and RUNEBOUND. I especially liked the ability to equip one's other minions (armies, henceman).
Unfortunately, I am not a fan of PVP, which this game seems to be built around. Further, there is too much counting of DEF and OFF points.
Cards are nice, and stacking them works well to count the stats... but there is just too much counting to make this fun.

item.name: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
History of the World
item.comment: Too long for what it is. Unlikely that I can be convinced to play this again.

item.name: History of War
item.comment: Nice images, unit abilities are good, but it takes too long to build units and things are too balanced that it comes down to card draw. In one game my opponent kept hitting my base, detroying one of my improvements, and I could do nothing as I had yet to get a fighter or AA unit...

item.name: Hitler's War
item.comment: Grand Strategic scale game. Each turn represents several months. Economic, Production, Research aspects covered. Interesting movement & combat system.

item.name: The Hobbit: An Unexpected Journey Deck-Building Game
item.comment:
Same engine as DC Comics and the LotR DBG from the same publisher.
Per the LotR games, the theme is well rendered, and minor tweaks in Characters, card types and Villain/Enemy deck, changes the game slightly.
Does it justify adding yet another copy in your collection? Maybe not, but if you're into LotR, why not, the images are nice, and there is a mention that the games can be combined.

item.name: Horus Heresy
item.comment:
Nice components, like the combat system. First game was a lot longer then expected.
I had to keep referring to the rulebook to determine if I could play a card or not; an image and/or color of units could have been added to the cards. Needs a player aid showing the various unit names as well as the name of each (color) faction (Khorne, etc.)
Hero's Space Marine color not obvious (I had trouble distinguishing between blue and purple).
Timing is everything here, and game requires at least a second play. (Rating will probably go up 1)

item.name: Ideology: The War of Ideas
item.comment:
Game suffers from the "snowball" effect. Once a player has gained momentum, stoping him/her alone is not possible.
Once someone has gained control of a neutral, it's way too easy for them to develop it.
Bash-The-Leader appears to be the best method to use to slow him/her down. If you're in the lead, screwing up your move is the best thing you can do, in order to drop a spot or two...
Best strategy is to let other players take care of the leader while you attempt to go for the win by sailing in from 2nd or 3rd place.
Each power has a special ability and a disability. Some of them make little sense, like Capitalism not being allowed to declare war.
Each player's deck is limited to 45 cards, which is an attempt to reduce the snowball effect, IMHO. Once you are at 10 points, you need to discard most if not all of your influence in other countries in order to concentrate on the 2-3 you control.
The rulebook is built around the turn order, which means you need to read the rules twice, as the first pass will provide you with info which should have been explained before the Turn Order Sequence.
The game is too pricey for the quality of the components, which are almost as thin as paper. As the 1 thru 6 counters were too difficult to pick up, we swapped them out for dice...
Essentially, this is a card game which could have done without the counters and paper map.
The Peace/Neutral/War diagram is cool, but would have been easier to read as an X-Y table (someone has uploaded one here!)
On the positive side, the turn order is well thought out.

item.name: Igloo Pop
item.comment: Nice bits, great for kids under 6. A tad annoying for what it is.

item.name: Iliad
item.comment:
Played with 5 and enjoyed it. This is an advanced Rock-Paper-Scissors game, with 8 different card types. The best defensive card is the Catapult, but it's worth 0 points, while the most useless offensive card is the Hoplite, which becomes the most potent, point wise, when you stack them in a Phalanx. You need to manage your hand in order not to overextend by playing too many cards, as all you get between rounds is 3 new cards.
The theme feels right for this one, and the other 4 players enjoyed it as well. Definately one we will be playing again! And the artwork is pretty good too.

item.name: Imperial
item.comment:
An interesting take on ANTIKE, but more complex. The action "wheel" is still present, and works similarly, although there is one spot which triggers the Investment sub-phase whenever a Country Action Token moves on or over it!
Each player will be playing two roles during the game. That of an Investor, purchasing Bonds from the various Countries, and that of a Government, deciding when to tax, produce units, move/attack as well as when to pay dividends.
Managing both of these can be difficult, as players may purchase Bonds on any Country, and the player with the most Bonds (total) forms the new Government (i.e. controls that Country).
Initially players may have difficulties as to where the money is placed. When a Country plays the Tax action, the money generated, if any, gets added to that Country's treasury. When the Country pays it's inventors, the money is taken from the Country's Treasury and paid to the players holding Bonds.
So you'll be spending your money investing in different Countries, which you can be certain will change hands more than once during the game. In the end, it is the player with the most money (cash on hand value of all Bonds) who wins.
Although I rated this a '7', I think my rating will go up after a few more plays.

item.name: Industria
item.comment: The special tiles and the links are a bit much. The randomness of the draw can and will affect the outcome. Got the impression that once behind I could not catch up to the leader as generating income is very difficult. Played with two other players. Would probably be better with 4. Willing to give it another try.

item.name: Ingenious
item.comment: Not really into this type of game, but found it interesting even with 4 players. There is some luck involved in drawing the right tiles.

item.name: Innovation
item.comment:
Really like the way the game plays, and the elegance and simplicity of the system.
Mind you the first few games may appear to be chaotic, until you learn what it is you need to do!
GET 5 different colored cards out ASAP, and splay, but don't neglect the dogma effects, as some are pretty good!!
It would be best to have a majority in at least one icon category, least you give your opponents an opportunity to act when it is not their turn. ;)

item.name: Jambo
item.comment:
An interesting 2-player game. Player interaction is mostly limited to a few "take that" cards, but this can be remedied by swapping out those cards with cards from the expansion :)
The utility cards and 5 actions per player keep this one moving at a good clip.

item.name: James Ernest's Totally Renamed Spy Game
Jungle Speed
item.comment:
A game where you need quick reflexes and probably a hockey helmet, as some players really "fight" for that center piece (I received it in the chest!).
As I'm not a big fan of this type of game, you need to take my rating with a grain of salt.

item.name: Junta
item.comment:
A lot of rules to learn for the first play. Requires a few turns to get into, but is relatively easy to play once thru the motions.
May be long for some as our first game took 4 hours and we still were not done. Too much negotiating, not enough revolutions.
Do expect a lot of randomness as the card draw might not be in your favor. You could have 1 vote for most of the game while everyone else has 6-12.
The revolution sub-game can be interesting as people switch sides at the start, during and at the end of this part of the game.
Needs to be played with the right type of people.
The French (Edition Descartes) version has a nicer board and counters, but the cards and money are much better with the English (West End Games) edition.
There are some differences in the rules as well, such as no initial attack in the English version when an enemy unit(s) enters your sector.

item.name: Justinian
item.comment: Rating based on a single game with 4 players. Game appeared to be way too chaotic, but we most likely played incorrectly.

item.name: Kalua
item.comment:
A filler type game, quick to play. I had the impression this was a work in progress, as it could be the base mechanic for a game on influence.
Did not find it fun/enjoyable, and as religion is not my cup of tea, will most probably not play this again.
Components: Nice plastic cubes and meeples!

item.name: Keythedral
item.comment: Did not like the fact that players can gang up on someone and there is nothing one can do. Quickly turns into a "take that" game. Not to mention that the choice of colors is pretty bad. Can't imagine what it's like for color blind folks!

item.name: Kingdoms
item.comment: This one was more interesting then I had expected! Some turn angst as you wait and see what the other players will do/play as everyone tries to maximize their rows/columns while minimizing the competition's!

item.name: Kingsburg
item.comment:
There is more game here than meets the eye! Gameplay is balanced, regardless of the fact that one rolls 3d6 at each production phase. The die rolls act as a limit to your actions, as you can get from 1 to 3 "rewards" each turn. The bonus " 2" markers and the Farm's extra white die work very well in this system.
During our first 4-player game, two players had not focused on scoring victory points, thus the spread was large. The second game saw a result of 36-35-35-32, with the player in last having dropped from 37 due to failing a combat against the dreaded Dragon.
Feels like a mix of ROMA, adding multiplayer capabilities, and CAYLUS, where resource management is key. Player interaction (i.e. blocking) is limited to the die placement on the Influence board. Players can build what they want on their "land" (board), assuming they have the required resources, and follow the building "tree" (which is very straight forward). The rules are easy to learn, and the game can be thought quickly.
This may just be the best light Euro in my collection!

item.name: Kogge
item.comment: Not my type of game.

item.name: Lancaster
item.comment:
Pretty straightforward game with nice quality components. Game play is dynamic and offers multiple paths and difficult choices at times.
Only played once with 5-players, all newbies, so the game lasted twice as long, but this one will see the gaming table again, soon.

item.name: Last Night on Earth: The Zombie Game
item.comment:
Only played one game, was attacked on the first turn, got my movement cancelled due to a locked door, fended off a zombie, moved 1 space, got attacked again, managed to kill it, but was then killed by another zombie after rolling a pair of "2" to the zombie's "3"...
The game components looked good, and although I watched the other 3 players, the game simply did not look fun. And when asked if they liked the game, the other players simply said that "something appears to be missing".
Will most likely be giving this one another go to see if we did something wrong, but it came across as a nice looking bad game.

item.name: Lawless
item.comment:
Could be more interesting, as I'm not a big fan of playing cards to screw over your opponent, and it's a big part of this game. The cattle hurding and trying to increase their value appears to be too light, as the focus is geared more towards trying to slow down, steal from or hinder your opponents.
Will still give this game another go, with more players.

item.name: Legendary Encounters: An Alien Deck Building Game
item.comment:
Rating after 10 games, averaging about 60 minutes per game.
Will undoubtedly be the best DBG of 2014.
Game mat comes with the game; finally someone who understands the advantage of a mat over a board!
The first scenario was the most difficult for us, and our sweet spot was to add 1 Drone card per player +1.
A great enhancement on the Legendary system!! Mechanically flawless, scales well, enjoyable, and brimming with theme.
The "coordination" mechanic adds to the Coop nature of the game. You are picking up cards which will assist your teammates, and playing one on their turn is necessary more often than not.
The added need to scan for enemies really adds to this game, and plays well with the theme. Once in the Combat Zone, you get attacked by each enemy present. Nice!
Giving the "3" strength Sergeants "Coordinate" and a Character Class is brilliant! Even low cost cards give you pause for consideration, depending on how you want to structure your deck.
Wounds do not clutter your deck, they accumulate besides your character until you are eliminated. Player elimination is mitigated by the Alien player additional rule, which essentially ensures the game will end much quicker, so you can start a new one. ;)
Although a 10 strength Alien is frightening, the worst enemy is the darn Facehugger!! "Ok, before scanning, be sure to keep at least 3 attack points in case you reveal a Facehugger !!!"
Only negative thing I can find... The name on each card indicating which deck they belong to is way too small... for me anyways.
At least one person I know picked up a copy with 50 duplicate cards... A slight assembly error, which the publisher immediately recognized and advised would be sending the missing cards (within the next 3 weeks).
Looking forward to trying this with the traitor rules!! The added angst must be exhilarating!

item.name: Legendary: A Marvel Deck Building Game
Leonardo da Vinci
item.comment:
An interesting euro game. You need to manage your resources, which in this case also include your workers. Should they be assigned to the lab where they can speed up the research on the various trinkets, or sent to town to pick up resources or special items.
I really bungled my first attempt at this one (bad strategy - did not know what to expect), and am willing to give it another go. Everything is important in this one, and you need to keep a close eye on the competition.
item.conditiontext: 2006 Mayfair Edition - still in shrink wrapping.

item.name: Liar's Dice
item.comment: Interesting yet fairly quick game. Can be very noisy with six shakers going at the same time. ;)

item.name: Loopin' Louie
item.comment: Picked this up to keep my niece busy. Everyone had to try it once... or more. Seems to have been a hit with most of the family.

item.name: Lord of the Rings
item.comment: A good coop game, with a lot of theme. Adding the Friends & Foes expansion makes the game somewhat more difficult. We've tried the Sauron expansion as well, with six players, and found the game too difficult to play. We'll have to try it again though.
item.conditiontext: In original shrink

item.name: Lord of the Rings: Friends & Foes
item.comment:
An interesting addition, although I am not all that fond of the base game, and the addition of the Friends and Foes does not increase my enjoyment.
On the positive side, I do like the two added locations, which seem to make the game more complete. I guess they were left out due to game length and cost.
item.conditiontext: Excellent - played a few times with cards in sleeves

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Card Game
item.comment:
Played two 4-player games with a single copy of the game (we took two Threat counters from another game), and the game played rather well. As we were all learning the cards, the games were a bit slower, but that was to be expected.
That said, I really liked the flow. Although there are quite a few steps, they become intuitive after a game or two.
The game is interesting, cards are nice, price is acceptable, and it is not a collectable, which all add up to an 8. Rating may change after a few more games, but I am already looking forward to the expansion(s), so we can start building our decks.
Looking forward to seeing where FFG intends to go with this.

item.name: The Lord of the Rings: The Fellowship of the Ring Deck-Building Game
item.comment:
An easy to learn and easy to play game. Combos are pretty straight forward, and the theme is well represented.
Like the fact that there are several deck reducing cards available, and the DEF cards have different effects. Really enjoy things like Frodo's use of the Ring card will has a chance of giving him a Corruption card.
Prefer this to it's DC COMICS predecessor.

item.name: Louis XIV
item.comment:
This is a thinking game, as you try to gain mission tokens by gaining the favor (majority of influence tokens) of a member of the court. Influence placement mechanic is quite interesting, and the game has many subtleties. Good reply value!
There is a bit of luck with the influence cards you are dealt, but this is practically negated since you have the option of moving influence tokens to an adjacent character, not to mention that you always have an extra influence card (therefore you will be discarding the least valuable).

item.name: Macao
item.comment:
Not for the faint of heart! An (Action) Cube management game!
It can be quite challenging to plan for the activation of cards when you have no control when, nor how many, cubes of the right color will come out!
Single color cards are easier to plan for, two colors doable but more difficult, but 3 and 4 colors? You really need to plan 5-6 turns ahead for those, and hope the right numbered dies come up, or you have a Joker token or have already activated card(s) which provide you with a cube of the needed color(s).
With this said, it is possible to, or should I say necessary, to go for card combos. And there are many possibilities.
Not all cards will come up during a game, so there is a lot of replay value. At the same time, there is a fair amount of randomness (cards, action cube die rolls), which is somewhat mitigated by the fact that there are more than one copy of a card, albeit with different resource costs. Further, there are always 2 extra cards during the card selection phase, so even the last player will have a choice out of 3 cards.
All in all an interesting game, but somewhat of a brain burner when it comes to planning ahead.
Weight: Medium Heavy (for a euro)

item.name: Die Macher
item.comment: An interesting game, but the luck of the draw can seriously hamper your options. Even though I seem to be able to draw nothing but policy cards I already had, I still liked the experience.

item.name: Machi Koro
item.comment:
A light-medium game which has a clean mechanic. There is a bit of "take that" (Coffee and purple buildings). Players gradually build up their Town, and the first to complete the construction of 4 pre-set buildings (everyone has the same 4) wins.
There is some randomness, but it can be mitigated by the cards you purchase, which trigger on different numbers, and may or not not trigger on other players turns.
A nice filler to end a game day, or while you wait for players to arrive. 30-45 minutes.

item.name: MagÂ·Blast (Third Edition)
item.comment: A rather light game, somewhat similar to NAVAL BATTLES. Easy to teach and play, but heavily dependant on card draw. Most probably better with more players. Some of the card drawings are funny/cute. Game does not appear to have anything to do with the TI universe (thought I had read that somewhere). Willing to give this one another try, with 4 or more players.
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Maharaja: The Game of Palace Building in India
item.comment: Only played once. Will need to play a few more times to get better impression of this one.

item.name: Mare Nostrum
item.comment:
A Political, Economic and light wargame of many subtleties. Each Empire starts off with a slight advantage in one area. Winning usually requires finess, in this most excellent game!
Initially, everyone races to increase their economies via the building of Caravans and Markets. Once these tokens have all been bought, players start increasing their military, which they hope to use in order to "help" with their Diplomacy :)
All battles (ground and naval) are resolved by rolling 1d6 per unit, totaling the result, then dividing by 5 to determine the number of enemy units destroyed.
The game's winner is usually the player who has played the best political game, or the one who has managed to put everyone to sleep and then builds the coveted Pyramid wonder!
The game is best played with 5, and is still Ok with 4. Unfortunately, it does not work too well with only 3.
A 3-player scenario (Triumvirate) has been published. Rating adjusted due to 3-player scenario!
item.conditiontext: Mint in original shrink wrapping - ENGLISH version Will only trade with [gameid=17099].

item.name: Mare Nostrum: Mythology Expansion
item.conditiontext: Mint, in original shrink wrapping. Will only trade with base game: [gameid=3931].

item.name: Mars
item.comment:
Nice quality components, but only an Ok game. The premise is interesting, and generally the game plays well.
Unfortunately, the "Conflict" resolution provides an advantage to the leader, an advantage that one cannot easily remove or negate.
The person with a Military advantage can steal, every turn, 1 resource from any player who does not match him. This is not too bad, but then there is the Military Conflict event, which allows one player to steal ALL the resources from another player. Further, once the Military Supremacy event card comes up, he gets to retain it, which allows him to steal half the resources from one player every turn.
The problem with this is that the only way to effectively counter a Military superiority is by building a Military building, or having the Bunker R&D card (there is only 1, drawn randomly). Since the Military superiority allows the player to steel resources, it is extremely difficult to counter as you seldom have the resources required to build what you'd like to, let alone a military building.
As it turned out, it's a catch-22 for one player, as it turns into a bash-the-player-in-last-place to steel the 1 or 2 resource cards he has. After all, one needs resources to build, thus why not steal from another player each turn?
Although I love resources management games, the "conflict" mechanic in this one is what killed it from me. I will probably try this again, knowing that at least one player will not have a good time, as he won't be able to build, let alone catch up to the rest of the group.
Click here for a more detailed review: [url]http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/385839[/url]

item.name: Masterpiece
item.conditiontext: Game in good condition, all "Arts" cards accounted for. May be missing two plastic clips (white), which are not absolutely required to play the game.

item.name: Megastar
item.comment: Not my type of game, as one does not have enough control. The mechanic and theme are fine, but something is missing.

item.name: Memoir '44
item.comment:
A "light" wargame which can be appreciated by grognards and beginners alike.
Played with 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 players (using a single copy of the game). Also tried with 8 players using two copies of the game. It was quite enjoyable, regardless of the number of players, as downtime is kept to a minimum.
Rulebook, mapboard, soft plastic units, counters and terrain tiles are of excellent quality (artilery pieces are a little thin).
Doublesided mounted mapboard with (2) isomorphic sides which allows for expansion of the battlefield by combining multiple copies of the game.
Game requires 10-15 minutes setup time (terrain tile and unit placement). Use of a Plexiglas to hold the tiles in place is recommended, but not necessary.
Card holders are a GREAT addition, as I used these with other card games!! :)
Card activation system minimizes "down time" and lends itself well to team play (players commanding one or more sectors of the battlefield --> Left/Center/Right).
Combat is resolved using special combat dice (8 are provided). One seldom rolls more than 4 dice, so no dicefest here.
Game comes with 16 scenarios, each playable in 30-60 minutes. Quick playing time allows for "round robin" type play.
Excellent game support offered via web site (here too!) as well as excellent customer service from Days of Wonder!
I liked the game and support so much I picked up a second copy!
[u]Expansions released in Oct. 2005[/u]: Eastern Front | Terrain Pack | Winter/Desert Map
item.conditiontext: Shrink (shrink is badly torn, but there is no box damage)

item.name: Memoir '44: Overlord
item.comment: These are rules which add an additional level of Command & Control, where the CinC is only allowed to talk to a single field/section commander, is clean and easy to implement. It just adds the right feel to this game (I still prefer [gameid=14105]).

item.name: Merchant of Venus
item.comment:
An excellent pick-up-and-deliver type game. Sure there is some randomness to your movement, but this beats drawing event cards. The resupplying mechanic works really well, as a route you've established may run dry (again random, but recreating uncertainty).
Although the game appears to start slowly, it does pick up speed as you generate more income. I am looking forward to playing again, perhaps with some of the advanced rules (like combat).

item.name: Merchants & Marauders
item.conditiontext: Near mint - box has been opened, never played. Cards are still shrink wrapped. Z-Man (English) Edition (2010)

item.name: Mice and Mystics
item.comment:
A Light to Medium weight adventure game, good to introduce new folks to the genre, yet challenging enough even for seasoned players.
Love the Initiative track and the ability cards. Everything works well with the theme.

item.name: Midway
item.comment: An interesting "blind" play system. The search is fun, but whoever finds the other's carrier first usually wins.

item.name: Mission Command Sea
item.comment: Ultra simplistic. Needs better rules as it boils down to whom rolls the highest. Fighters have a rating from 2 - 4, which dictates how many dice you roll for them. Payload can be either Air-to-Air (+1 to a die) or Air-to-Sea. If you loose the die tosses for both your 4 rated fighters, the game becomes very difficult. In our first game, I lost my two '4' fighters, the first to bad die rolls, and the second to a lucky die roll from the opponent (his '2' rated fighter armed with AA rolled a 6, which turned into a 7, thus defeating my roll of 6-6-6-6... Quite annoying, considering the odds. All this to say that lady luck plays a big role. The components are very nice, but not really worth the asking price. If you like tweaking rules, this game has some potential.

item.name: Mission: Red Planet
item.comment: Was somewhat disappointed by this one. Perhaps we were not playing it right. Willing to give it another try.

item.name: Monopoly
item.comment: This was my first game. It was great back then, but has not seen the table top in over 20 years.

item.name: Mow
item.comment: Really not my type of game... Too light, next to no strategy, and it is next to impossible to target the player across the table from you.

item.name: Mr. Jack
item.comment:
A quick playing game of strategy and deduction. One player tries to eliminate suspects, while the other tries to move the pieces to make the first player's task more difficult.
Game pieces are of excellent quality! There was a problem when they cut the cards as the card's color is visible on the sides (a bad thing). They suggest placing the deck in the box so the side is not visible. This solution works quite well.

item.name: Municipium
item.comment: I like the halo idea (green marker) and the name is cool! Unable to find the "game" in this one...

item.name: Nautilus
item.comment: Nice board and bits. Game play is pretty straight forward, with 3 mechanics in play: Resource Management (your Researchers and $$$), Tile laying (underwater "City"), and Exploration (submarines picking up Atlantis and other tokens).

item.name: Naval Battles
item.comment: It's an Ok game, which plays relatively fast. I preferred [thing=17208][/thing]'s system.

item.name: Nefertiti
item.comment:
A set collecting game, where one collect cards by placing pawns in different markets. The market mechanic is new (to me), as a certain number and/or placement of pawns will trigger the closing of the market, which allows the owner of the pawn in the highest numbered slot to pay that price to get first pick (top card in the market + a favor, or two cards in the lower row). The next pawn owner, in numerical order, has the option of taking half the money in the market, rounded up, or purchasing a card for the price his/her pawn is on. This continues until all player pawns have had a chance to act.
With the favors, players are able to activate special cards, which will help them in scoring victory points. At the end of the game, each card is worth a value, based on the number of different players who own that type of card. The more owners there are, the less a card is worth.
An interesting system, but something appears to be missing, as there could be more then just set collecting. Then again, perhaps my expectations are too high.

item.name: New World: A Carcassonne Game
item.comment: Not really into this type of game. New "explorer" mechanic which removes your unscored meeple(s) works well.

item.name: Nexus Ops
item.comment: Light war game. Has elements of Victory and Axis & Allies. Subtle strategies possible due to cards.

item.name: NHL Ice Breaker: The Card Hockey Board Game
item.comment:
Light game where you face off against an opponent (or 2 pairs of players). Each hand is played against a single opponent, the winner moving the puck up the ice as per the instructions on the last card played.
When in the shooting zone, hand winner determines if it is a goal or a save.
Your 5-card hand is refilled only when there is a stoppage in play or you run out of cards.
Duration: 30-45 minutes

item.name: Niagara
item.comment: The river mechanic is nice. Game becomes repetitive after the 2nd turn... Then again, I'm not particularly fond of games where everyone has the exact same movement cards, turn after turn.

item.name: Ninja: Legend of the Scorpion Clan
item.comment:
Friend got it in a bargain bin @ $25. Nice components, interesting game play
Played twice. Too long for what it is. Next to impossible to win as the guards, as even if you kill both opponents, if it's before turn #9, they come back...What's the point? To help the guards, if you did not draw an attack card, you can't do anything even if you find the opponents. Really? Don't intend to play this again.

item.name: No Thanks!
item.comment: This one is difficult to describe, it is a game of card taking and passing, as each card taken is worth x points, and the person with the lowest total wins. Only the lowest number in a sequence is counted, so 19,18, 17 is only worth 17 points. Each player starts with 11 tokens, which can be used to pass ("no thanks"), with the person taking the card also taking the tokens which were placed on it to pass.

item.name: Notre Dame
item.comment: A good game, with some interesting mechanics (like the action card draft) and bribing a worker (available to all for 1 gold). Multiple paths to victory, but player interaction is somewhat limited (card draft and moving the wagon).

item.name: Once Upon a Time: The Storytelling Card Game
item.comment: Not really into this type of game...

item.name: Oshi
item.comment: Fairly easy to play, but may take some time to master. There are three different types of pieces, which can move 1, 2 or 3 spaces (depends on the size/height of the piece). Each of these may move/push up to 1, 2 or 3 pieces, again depending on the size/height. The first person to push off the board 7 points worth of pieces from his/her adversary wins. And you guessed it, each piece is worth 1, 2 or 3 points, based on it's size/height.

item.name: Owner's Choice
item.comment:
Talk about a short game! 45 minutes? Actually took us 20-25 minutes with 5-players. Perhaps we were doing something wrong? When it's your turn you buy/sell stocks (optional), advance the purple pawn around the board (1-3 spaces) and do what is on that space.There is not much game here, as is it feels like the game has not been completed. There are much better games out there such as [GAMEID=433], even [GAMEID=2680] is better, IMHO. I'm rather disappointed in this one, although some players were already coming up with house rules to make the game better.
The dice: aren't we past the point where we have to apply stickers onto dice? And there are six in this one... I can see these labels waring/peeling off fairly quickly.
The four modular "L" which make up the board's contour is interesting, as it allows the board's layout to change from game to game, but players often moved the board (accidentally) and it seems we kept replacing these sections. Perhaps a "puzzle" type approach would have been better?
On the positive side, the stock tokens are a good size, and the thickness is excellent!
[u]Edit[/u]: Upped rating from 3 to 6 after my gaming partner suggested each move be 1 or 2 squares instead of up to 3. It made the game way more interesting and less chaotic.

item.name: Pack & Stack
item.comment:
Family game, easy to learn and play. Nice components. May be a bit pricey for what you get.
The Action/Dexterity must be for the rush to not be the last one to grab a truck once they are revealed... It's more family friendly when you play with the optional rule which allows you to choose a truck off the table when you are last; takes a few seconds longer, but gives the 3D challenged players a better chance.

item.name: Palazzo
item.comment: Set building... meh.

item.name: Pandemic
item.comment:
I like coop games, and this one lends itself well to it. Trying to maximize the entire team's play may be overwhelming for some, who may think the other players are playing for them. Truth is, players should make recommendations as to what they think the optimal moves are, else this may just has well be a one player game. With this being said, I liked the game and the folks I played it with, thus I had a good experience and would play it again.
The components are nice, and the epidemic mechanic, where the discard deck is added to the top of the draw deck works great, giving the feel of an epidemic/outbreak.

item.name: Pandemic: On the Brink
item.comment: Gives new life to Pandemic. New roles are interesting, and the added stuff makes the game more difficult to win.

item.name: Parthenon: Rise of the Aegean
item.comment:
This is an empire building game with a risk management component. I must say I was surprised how balanced the game could be, as I had the impression the random events had taken me out of the game on three occasions, yet I was one turn away from winning at the end of the third year.
The Island Trading aspect reminds me of CIV, as it's open and everyone tries to trade for the resources he/she needs. Planning and the ability to think on your feet pays dividends here.
One must take advantage of the Surplus and Shortages which are occuring on the board, but must also take into account if these are occuring at a neighboring land or further away, as the number of event cards doubles.
Rating is based on a single play. I am looking forward to trying this one again as my rating will most likely go up!

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â Base Set
item.comment:
Plusus: + has a good D&D feel + plays quickly + little downtime + good character selection (7 base + 4 in Character pack) + each character plays differently (special ability + card types) + character (deck) building + built in campaign system + good replay-ability + very decent price + good support on the Paizo site + game is fairly intuitive (after 1-2 scenarios)
Minusus: - some erratas on a few cards - FAQ is HTML only

item.name: Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Rise of the Runelords â Character Add-On Deck
Pathfinder Adventure Card Game: Skull & Shackles â Base Set
Paydirt
item.comment: A rather interesting football simulation. All plays are based on the actual team's statistics. Unfortunately, one is no longer able to find any updated team charts...

item.name: Penguin Pile-Up
item.comment: A filler, more for kids, but can be appreciated by adults with a steady hand.

item.name: Pergamon
item.comment:
Nice quality components, love the reduction in interest of previous/older exhibits.
Game requires $$ to do anything, and if you are unlucky, can lead to a pretty boring game. You need to predict what the other players need, how much cash they will most likely require to pick the item up, and you'll have to try to predict how much cash will be available. More likely then not, someone will play before you and get the cash and the item, then you are left not doing much of anything for the turn... If there are a few rounds with low income, the game drags...
Too long for what it is, and too random when it comes to $$, which is absolutely required if you want to dig for relics.

item.name: Perikles
item.comment: Was not overly impressed by the game play in this one, although the mechanics are interesting, and the pieces are nice.

item.name: Pickomino
item.comment: A light dice game where one attempts to roll the highest total. Players may re roll as often as they want, and must select a dice # which they have not selected previously. Further, at least one worm is needed in order to obtain a tile.

item.name: The Pillars of the Earth
item.comment: Good game, with limited choices. Only played once, in 90 minutes, and think this game could be played even faster (3 of us were new to this game). Recommended.

item.name: Pirate's Cove
item.comment: Easy to learn and fast playing game. Players select which island they are going to and combat occurs if more than one player goes to the same island. Only one player gets to collect the booty (listed on a card) for each island. Nice components. Played many 4 and 5 player games. The addition of an extra Pirate ship should make the game scale well with three players, as it limits ones choices. The 4-player game is what I prefer to date.

item.name: Pitch Bowl
item.comment:
Knowledge of the rules of football is not required in this relatively simple game. The pieces are of good quality, and "pitching" the tokens works really well as the playing surface provides more friction, therefore one has more control.
The rules are a tad ambiguous, and I'd like to read them again before deciding to purchase this one or not, although I am very tempted to pick this up!

item.name: PitchCar
item.comment:
This is a fast playing dexterity game. Players may position their "car" to "snooker" you, so there is more strategy then meets the eye.
Unless you're really bad at dexterity games, it's always possible to come back from behind to win!
A game can be played in about 15-20 minutes with 4-6 players. This is a big plus, especially when compared to other more detailed games which take 2-3 hours to play.
Last but not least, it's a game the whole family can play.

item.name: PitchCar Mini Extension
item.comment: Not as enjoyable as it's big brother, but perfect for kids.

item.name: Pizza Box Football
item.comment:
All the rules of (North American) Football are there, except for penalties. Come on, it would not have been too difficult to implement.
As for gameplay, you don't really get a feeling that you are usefull when playing on Defense, as even if you guess the right play, all it provides is perhaps a minus 1 modifier if you rolled high enough, or a -2 if you rolled 2 or 12 (on 2d6).
As is, this is more of a solo game than anything else. Perhaps it would be easy to come up with house rules so that the defensive player would get an immediate modifier for selecting the correct counter-play.
If the offensive player rolls well, there is absolutely nothing the defensive player can do. By the same token, if the offensive player rolls badly (less then 10 on 3d6), there is nothing the defense needs to do.
On the positive side, the components are of good quality, and I especially like the fact that the reference cards are laminated.
There are better games on the subject out there, including AH's PAYDIRT!, which was released in the late 70's-early 80's.

item.name: Pizza Box Football Expansion
item.comment:
Provides minor modifications to the generic/base cross-reference chart, with teams having a slight modifier for Run, Short Pass and/or Long Pass type plays, but providing an extra die to roll (one takes the higher of two die when his team has an advantage in that specific type of play, or the lower of the two when it has a disadvantage).
The expansion does add 3 more plays, or rather one extra play per type of play (Run/Draw, Short Pass/Screen, Long Pass/Play Action). These in turn provide the defensive player with a slight improvement in usefulness, as if he guesses the play right, he has an increased chance of affecting the offense's die roll, by providing a -1 modifier.
Still, the defensive player's role in the game is very minimal, as his guessing the correct counter play does not impact the game all that much. If the Offensive player rolls high (10 on 3d6), there is absolutely nothing the defensive player can do, unless he rolls 10 on 2d6 AND guesses the correct counter-play.

item.name: Planet Steam
item.comment: First game was rather confusing... need to reread the rules to ensure we've played it correctly.

item.name: Police Precinct
item.comment:
Of the negative comments I have read here, I agree there are typos, the tokens/counters are a little small, and the rulebook could have been better organized, but apart from that, this is a pretty decent game.
Played 3 games in a row, 4-player configuration without the dirty cop. We lost the first two, and one the last one, on the very last turn and player action of the game!
The theme is well integrated, there is some randomness which can be mitigated by player cooperation.
Downtime is limited, as you can always interact/assist with the active player.
Game is fairly simple to learn, and pretty well balanced right out of the box.
The sweetspot appears to be a 4-player configuration, since adding more player reduces the over # of turns, and increases the time between turns.
Components are of good to medium quality, except for the crime track and evidence boards, which are too thin (and start warping as soon as you open the box).
With the variable setup, the game is different enough to make it an interesting puzzle to solve.

item.name: Ponte del Diavolo
item.comment: Meh, just not my type of game. There are so many better 2-player games out there.

item.name: Portobello Market
item.comment: A fairly straight forward euro game where the goal is to out score your opponents. Simple mechanic, without a clear cut way to win, so different strategies may work.

item.name: Power Grid
item.comment: Easy to learn and plays fairly quickly (~2 hours) for this type of game. Very good Supply & Demand resource system!

item.name: Power Grid: Benelux/Central Europe
item.comment:
The BeNeLux board with is minor rules modifications is the best one I have played so far. Game time is also reduced to about 90 minutes, given the removal of the lowest rank Power Plant every turn (which we had forgotten to do!)
It needs a small player aid/reminder, which could be placed on the board somewhere, for the first session or two.
(Belgium, Netherlands, Luxembourg)

item.name: Power Grid: Factory Manager
item.comment: Management is a tad more complex than Power Grid. Game is Ok and relatively short.

item.name: Power Grid: The First Sparks
item.comment:
Did not like the added disadvantage the leading player has when selecting an item from the market. Essentially, you have to select something no one else wants, which is counter-intuitive.
Random board and tribesman placement is Ok, but does not make up for the lack of control the leading player has due to dwindling food supply, which is again counter-intuitive unless you start calculating what everyone else can get in order to know how much you will have...
Did not like this one, and will most likely not be playing it again.

item.name: The Princes of Florence
item.comment:
Pretty good game which includes bidding, and where one needs to manage his actions and resources.
The "Tetris" approach to placing buildings is quite interesting, and players are more tempted to pick up a 2nd Engineer to allow adjacent placement, else one runs out of room very quickly!
Very touch decision between collecting money for your Works, or getting Victory Points! If a player mis-manages his/her resources (money), he/she may take themselves right out of the game. Thus, need to pre-plan their next move(s).

item.name: Princes of the Renaissance
item.comment: As per usual Martin's game include some interesting mechanics. Unfortunately, it was unclear to me how to achieve victory as I seemed to always be short on funds, even though a lot of the bids went to the first bidder (no one appeared to have money). I have only played one game, and managed to come in first, although I am not sure how. May have given it a better rating, although I am not sure I would like to play this one again.

item.name: Privacy
item.comment:
This is a light party game which is a great Ice Breaker! Can play up to 12-players, and would recommend a minimum of 5 or 6.
In a nutshell, one player reads one of 6 (?) questions one one of the cards, and everyone "votes" via their Yes/No card, which they place in the voting box, then everyone guesses how many "Yes" can be found.
Everyone who guessed exactly the number of yeses scores 2 points. If there are no exact guess(es), then everyone who is within "1" of the number of Yesses scores 1 point.
First player to 10 points is the winner.
item.wishlistcomment:
Looking for ballot box version.
Please feel free to suggest a trade, or let me know how much you are asking for your copy.
Please list the condition of your copy. Thanks.

item.name: Prosperity
item.comment:
Although you only have 2 actions per turn, they are not always obvious, as you need to compare the advantages and disadvantages as well as the risks. Do you simply upgrade or go for more as that resource tile has not come up...
All in all a good game which is fairly easy to learn.

item.name: Puerto Rico
item.comment: Rather bland as there is little player interaction, other than blocking. Interesting role mechanic, which is similar to CITADELS, and copied in TI3. Gave away my copy.

item.name: Quarriors! Dice-Building Game Set-up Box
item.comment:
I like the concept, but the in game execution is iffy as you are rolling dice after all...
Attacking everyone simultaneously takes care of the bash the leader issue the game could have, but at the same time prevents weaker players from catching up.
I've seen 3-player games were we'd like to stop the leader, but roll nothing useful to attack with, and the game ends with scores of 2-2-15, which gives the impression there is a runaway leader issue.
After several additional plays, I have increased my rating to 5.5, but the runaway leader issue is flagrant, especially when someone gets one of the more expensive die at the start (such as the dragon).
Would like to try one or two of the expansions to see if it resolves any of the above issues, else I don't see the rating going any higher.

item.name: Quest for the DragonLords (Second Edition)
item.comment:
Tried one game, only played 3-4 turns, but had enough. It's a light combat game with a Fantasy component (Quest). The Quest part apears interesting, but somehow not feel right for this type of game. Counting territories each time to figure out how much income one receives is just too long. Having one player go through all 7 steps creates a lot of down time in a four player game (5 minutes per player per turn). Then again, this should come down once the players get accustomed to the rules, etc. I would be willing to give this one another try, but my first impression is not all that good, unfortunately.
Was there supposed to be a Mana marker? We ended up using one of the white markers. The cards where not the same size with about a quarter being wider than the rest. My copy was missing 1 red foot unit.
On the bright side, the Def/Att rating idea is interesting, in that your attack rating is what you need to roll (or less) to hit, while the defense rating of your target defines the dice type you need to roll (6 = 1d6, 12 = 1d12, etc.).

item.name: Quicksand
item.comment: Way too light for my tastes. Could be a good kids game though.

item.name: Ra
item.comment:
A fairly straightforward bidding game where everyone's possible bids are in plain view (each player has 3 numbered bidding tiles).
One tries to make different sets in order to score points, or avoid loosing points.
Better with 4-player than only 3, IMHO.

item.name: Race for the Galaxy
item.comment:
Has a CCG feel in that cards can/should be used in combos. There is little player interaction, other than the fact that you all draw from the same deck, and that the action you select (out of 7 or 8 choices) also allows the other players to do it (minus the bonus, a-la Puerto Rico). Cost to "build/activate" a card is done a-la San Juan, where you need to discard a card.
An interesting combination of mechanics, and a relatively fast playing game (under an hour).

item.name: Rail Baron
item.comment: A fun game for the whole family, pretty easy to learn and play, yet requires some planning as to which track you will use (and whom you will pay) to get to your destination.

item.name: Red November
item.comment: This is a light humoured coop game. Do expect to die a few times in this one, as the room you are in gets flooded or catches fire. If you drink grog and pass out, chances are you will not wake up.

item.name: Relic
item.comment:
I was looking forward to trying this one, but the movement is too close to MONOPOLY for me (roll 1d6 and move x spaces left or right). In 2013? Really??
Played a 4-player game and it was a waste of 3-hours of my life. No fun, no enjoyment, no control.
After 2 hours, managed to lose the only 4 points/trophy I had accumulated... and after 3 hours, still had not gained a level. Other players were passing their tests, I was failing more than half of them.
The board was nice but too "loud".
Nice sculpts.
Will never play this again.

item.name: The Resistance
item.comment:
Sweet spot is probably between 6 and 8 players. With 10, it can be very difficult to figure out who the double agents are...
The advanced cards add to the experience, and make the game more playable.
Is all about the table talk, and it plays quickly!

item.name: Revolution: The Dutch Revolt 1568-1648
item.comment:
Rating based on a single attempt with 5-players, none of which had played before. I will definitely be trying this one again, when I have had the time to re-read the rules (and print a player aid).
Given the level of detail in the sequence of play (20 or so phases in each turn!), I suspect there is a good game here, but it is not for the faint of heart. If you are not ready to invest a good chunk of time, do not attempt to play this one.
The conflict resolution mechanic stems from Civilization.

item.name: Ricochet Robots
item.comment: Will likely never play this again as it really is not the type of game I enjoy. It may appeal to gamers who like to solve puzzles, as this is what this game is all about (plus you have a timer). If you're not into puzzle solving, steer clear.

item.name: Risk
item.comment: Ahh, my first "war" game. I have the first edition with wooden pieces, and we played this over and over. The "card set" mechanic unbalances the game, IMHO, as each set is worth more than the previous, and the last player to hand in a set has the upper hand. It's easy to play king maker, and the winner is often decided 1 hour before the game actually ends.

item.name: Roads & Boats
item.comment: Excellent, just my type of resource management game!

item.name: Robinson Crusoe: Adventures on the Cursed Island
item.comment:
The theme blends flawlessly into this one.
Nice components, although some tokens should have been cards (ie. discovery tokens).
Excellent support by the author on this site.
One of the best coop games out there.
Learning curse may be steep for the first game, as there are lot of different tokens and cards. After one play, everything should be clear, as the system becomes intuitive.

item.name: RoboRally
item.comment:
This is a good game if you're interested in adding a little spice (and chaos) to your evening. "Programming" your bot is fairly straight forward, provided you have been passed the cards you need (if you didn't get any left turns, you may have to turn right a few times to get your bot to point in the right direction).
I liked the simultaneous moves and the special ability cards, but the game is a tad too long, random and chaotic for my tastes, so I sold my copy. YMMV.

item.name: Roll Through the Ages: The Bronze Age
Roma
item.comment:
Fairly straight forward two player game, which is a bit heavier than the standard fare filler game. I like the (random) way your 3 actions are determined, and the game is just the right length for what it is.
Unfortunately, if your opponent keeps rolling high and you roll low, it can be quite difficult to win.
I have yet to win a single game when I have the Merchant. The Gladiator on the opponent's side can be quite frustrating, especially when you have nothing to counter it. :(

item.name: Rome: Imperium, Circus Maximus, Hannibal vs Rome
item.comment:
3 $10 games in a $40 box... I did not like any of these, and it is this one that convinced me that Mr. Knizia's games are too lite for my tastes.
Traded for an old copy of Richthofen's War.

item.name: Rukshuk
item.comment:
It's a dexterity game, which is not my type of game. In a party/group setting, it's OK, as it plays relatively fast (30-40 minutes). The game can be frustrating as you only have 1 minute (or 90 seconds?) to build a structure, and the slightest bump against the table will bring your stack crumbling down.
When you play this, please ensure the table is sturdy enough to withstand a bump, else everyone's structure will collapse.

item.name: Rummikub
item.comment: Interesting game, but a bit of a brain burner. Nice components

item.name: Rune Age
item.comment:
Only played the coop game. Initial coop is rather difficult, if you don't have the right mix of races.
With the expansion [gameid=124300], the included coop is more enjoyable.
As a versus game, it is probably good, as each race has it's strengths and weaknesses.
Each race feels and plays very differently! Typical Corey Konieczka goodness! :)

item.name: Runebound (First Edition)
item.comment:
It's an interesting game, which can also be played solo. I really liked the movement dice idea, with multiple icons per side, allowing you to enter one area per dice with the appropriate terrain icon.
The game itself is fairly straightforward, although the game's time clock (monsters killed) really forces you to forge ahead. If you waste any time, you will not survive the final battle!
Oh yeah, there are a gazillion expansions for it, from new adventures to new monsters, to new items and treasures.

item.name: Runebound (Second Edition)
item.comment:
This is a good game. It's a light adventure game where the player controls a party of 1 to 3 characters (1 Hero and up to 2 Allies).
The combat is pretty straight forward, as players add 2d10 with their ability rating, and compare that number with the creatures rating. This may easily become monotonous.
The market mechanic is interesting, as players visit towns where they may purchase items, hire allies, pay to recoup stamina and/or health, not to mention sell items (for half price).
The players control which ability of his/her Hero will be upgraded when he/she reaches the next experience level (required XP varies based on number of players).
The XP provided by creatures varies depending on the deck it came from: Green = 1, Yellow = 2, Blue = 3 and Red = 4.
The game may appear to be long at first when you are learning to play, but it quickly becomes intuitive. Even Player versus Player combat is pretty easy.
Adding expansions will be rather straight forward, so there is no need to worry about replayability. Creative players could easily design their own adventures, creatures and items!

item.name: Runebound: Crown of the Elder Kings
item.comment: There are some good elements in this one, but unfortunately I am not a fan of Player versus Player, which is what this expansion is mostly about.

item.name: Runebound: The Island of Dread
item.comment:
This expansion includes a new adventure deck, which has more quests. It makes the game more interesting, to me anyways.
There are still a few things I don't like, such as the experience levels, which are a tad difficult to achieve initially, then are too easy/fast later in the game. The game clock using the Doom Counters is also a feature I do not enjoy, yet I understand why it is part of the game.

item.name: Ruse & Bruise
item.comment: Fairly easy card game. With only three cards in hand at any one time, it is fast to play. Waiting for the right combo may take some time.

item.name: Saint Petersburg: New Society & Banquet Expansion
San Juan
item.comment:
I like games where cards are multi-purpose as it forces you to make some tough choices.
Definitely prefer this one over Puerto Rico.

item.name: Santiago
item.comment: It can be difficult when you play last in a 5-player game. Having played with experienced players, I had the impression I did not have much control.

item.name: Santy Anno
item.comment:
A light and fast game of deduction, based on a set of displayed cards; one has to find his/her way to the (right) ship using the color coded Crow's Nest, Sails, Hull or Name Plate. The faster you are to get to your seat (the ship where your crew members ends up), the more gold you get. After 5 rounds, the game ends.
The components are nice, but where's the fun? It is as entertaining as watching paint dry. Would have rated a '1', but since this mathematical puzzle is not 'broken', I had to give it a '2'.

item.name: The Scepter of Zavandor
item.comment:
This game came across as an advanced GOA, where you need to manage your "funds" (magic dust and power/cash?) in order to upgrade your different skills in 6 (?) different abilities/books. Essentially, you are trying to build up your capital so you can afford the better items (VP and/or bonuses) and gems (cash).
When a player selects an artifact, a round of bidding is conducted until everyone passes.
There are a lot of cardboard pieces in this one, as those are used to represent your magic dust as well as your money/power. And you keep collecting and spending/returning those all the time. A tad too tedious for my tastes.

item.name: Scotland Yard
item.comment: Plays relatively quick and is easy to learn; players need to work as a team in order to corner Mr. X! Don't forget to manage your cards right, as you may know exactly where Mr. X is, but if you don't have the right transportation card to get there, you're SOL.

item.name: Senji
item.comment:
Have been wanting to play this one for some time, and was able to play a 6-player game with experienced players (I was the only newbie).
A nice game of Diplomacy, with better mechanics and good looking components.
I especially liked the combat resolution system, which I prefer over a similar (but a tad more complex) game of Wallenstein/Shogun. But there is no reason (other than prohibitive cost!) to not have colored the combat dice, as we were constantly asking which color those icons represented!
Hidden runaway leader problem, with one player going from last place with 28 points, and scoring a whopping 68 points in a single turn (game ends when a player passes 60 points), outscoring 2nd place by 30+ points... I guess everyone else simply missed a good game.... (Score: 96, 63, 62, 61, 58, 57)
And for the life of me, why would anyone not wait until the last turn to cash in their Hanafuda cards?
This is actually a set collecting game, set in Medieval Japan with a War/Diplomacy sub-game, similar to IMPERIALISM (where stocks is where the game's at.. in this case it is set collecting cards).
House Rule: Only one set of cards is allowed to be "cashed" in per turn.

item.name: Sentinels of the Multiverse
item.comment:
Increased rating from 6.5 to 7.0. I tend to enjoy playing the simpler characters (Tempest), while my gaming group enjoy the more complicated ones.
Game becomes fairly intuitive after a few plays. We assign one player to handle the Villain and Environment decks.
Sorting the tokens/markers helps.
Decks are pre-built, so you get right into the action.

item.name: Serenissima (first edition)
item.comment: A fast playing (light) trading game set in the Mediterranean. Combat is possible between ships as well as amphibious landings. Movement is cleverly limited by the number of sailors on each ship, with each sailor taking up one cargo hold. The more sailors the less cargo, but the faster the ship may move. Game ends after a set number of turns. This can be varied using an optional rule. Although fast playing, I find it too short.

item.name: Seventh Hero
item.comment:
Obviously a filler game, I was pleasantly surprised as to the depth and strategy of this one.
Can be played by the whole family, and can be a very good filler for experienced gamers too!

item.name: Shadows over Camelot
item.comment:
Played over 40 times.
Played with 3, 4, 5, 6 and 7 players. The game scales really well, not to mention players can enter or leave the game at any time, thus removing the need of running a filler while waiting for late arrivals.
In order to experience this game at its fullest, it is critical one aderes to the rules in that no specific information is provided. General comments are fine, but no details can be provided. Thus, "I can fight the Dragon but cannot defeat it" means that a player can play some cards but does not have all the cards required to win that Quest, thus help is needed. What kind of help? (i.e. which cards?) That's what can't be told.
The game can be difficult to win without a traitor, and can quickly become impossible to win when there is a traitor in your midst. You must observe every player's actions in order to see if there is indeed a traitor.
During the "Progression of Evil" phase, the player has to choose between three options, all of which are bad, so picking the one which is least damaging to your cause can be nail biting!
When playing the Knight's action phase, you must try to maximize your EVERY move. One wasted move can have nasty consequences.
Selflessness goes a long way as it can help another Knight, who in turn may be able to help you.
Since the priority of the different quests varies from game to game, there is a lot of replay value in here! Each Knight's special ability mixes things up even more.
An awesome game! Kudos to DoW for another winner!

item.name: Shadows over Camelot: Merlin's Company
item.comment: The extra cards and Knights give new life to the game. The Travel Cards also add another random element. Together, I got the impression the game was a bit more difficult to beat. I am looking forward to playing this again.

item.name: Shark
item.comment: There are some interesting mechanics in this one, as you need to plan your moves.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Board Game
item.comment:
There is a lot going on here, and a few games are required to grasp, let alone rate this title.
As a 2-player game, there is a runaway leader issue, but it's OK if all you want to do is learn the game.
As a 3-player game, it's OK if all three players have relatively the same experience level (ie. a new player might be an easy target for a Military victory).
As a 4-player game, the players are the balancing factor and can mitigate a runaway leader. The game is also more forgiving if you are relatively new to the game.
With multiple paths to victory, and a lot of options, this is an excellent game, although some might find it too long.
Expect Analysis Paralysis from new players.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Boardgame
item.comment:
Very nice pieces (except the plane and Battleship). The City improvement card system works well.
Combat is very basic using a Rock-Paper-Scissors modifier system as well as a 1d6 x Epoch approach which makes epoch changes extremely drastic initially.
The Technology and Wonder mechanic does not work for me, as I have a major issue with having a 5gp payback to the player who discovered the relevant technology first, since it makes attacking him next to pointless since you are in fact subsidizing his war effort. This is especially true in the first stages of the game as military units cost 10gp...
From what I have seen, whomever can pick up the technologies first will win the game, especially the military unit ones.
When a player is trailing, come backs are very difficult, which make these players easy targets for wealthier opponents.
Although I'm sure there is a good game lying somewhere in here, I was unable to see it, unfortunately.

item.name: Sid Meier's Civilization: The Card Game
item.comment:
A resource management game, where you produce 3 types of commodities (Food, Hammers, Coins). There are no dice, and the randomness of the card draws is somewhat mitigated by the fact that you draw 4 cards, then discard 2 from your entire hand. You can still end up with cards you can't really use.
The "terrain" system revolves around "Plot" cards, which produce 2 resources, or 1-2 types. You may allocate population on each resource, at the cost of 6,8, 10, etc. FOOD per population on the card, and they yield 1 additional resource this plot produces (your choice if there are 2).
Buildings and Wonders are built (Hammers) on the plots, 1 per card, 2 if you have 3 or more population on it. You may purchase additional plots at the cost of 15, 20, 25, etc. resources (of any kind) from the available ones (3 are always displayed/available).
You may also purchase any number of Tech cards, using coins, and they give you a bonus of some sort, as well as 1VP. The tech cards also act as the game clock; as soon as the last one is purchased, the game ends, and VPs are tallied up. Wonder cards are the only other unit which have a VP value.
Like Settlers of Catan, there are two cards which one may control over the course of the game, and those are for the most "Happy faces" and "Culture", and they provide a bonus to the current leading player.
