Combat is simplistic but works. Cards are rated for Offensive and/or Defensive action, and act in a rock-paper-scissor fashion. As an example, Archers here are defensive only, but can counter any single opponent card.
You play 1 to n combat cards on your enemy, who then has the option to counter them one by one, as he/she chooses. Non countered units execute their "action", which can be anything from capturing a population to destroying a building (it returns to your hand). Wonders cannot be destroyed, and plots are never stolen.
When there is a choice, the defender chooses which population or building is affected.
Played two-player and liked it (final score was 23 to 21), but think this would be better with 3 or 4, and I would be interested in trying the Team variation.
On the negative side, the game is too long for what it is, but if you are looking for a quick playing "light" Civilization game, this one is good. After all, what's 1-2 hours compared to 12 for Advanced Civilization? ;)

item.name: Skip-Bo
item.comment: Easy to teach and fast to play. Planning is possible. Team play is best for me.

item.name: Sky My Husband
item.comment:
A light "party" game which plays quickly. Can only be played by folks who understand both French and English, as one needs to translate French words back to English (English words were initially translated directly to French, Ã la Babblefish, which makes for a lot of nonsense).
When players cannot find the correct English words/translation, up to 2 clues are provided. Here's an actual example:
"Baton de joie" Answer: Joystick Clues were: Jeu vidÃ©o/Manette
When one translates "BÃ¢ton de joie" directly to English, one gets "Stick of Joy", hence the totally hilarious aspect of the game.

item.name: Slap Shot
item.comment:
Played a few sessions with some friends and found the game entertaining. It's a bit more advanced then the old card game where one team would "pass" by playing the same numbered card as the other team, and a goal would be scored on the next "play" by playing another matching card.
In this one you need to "move" the puck from zone to zone by playing "situation" cards. When in the offensive side of the ice but still in the neutral zone, a slap shot can be played, or a wrist shot when in the offensive zone.
Following play of each card the other team has the option of blocking play by playing an "Interception", "Off-side", "Icing", "Penalty" or other similar cards.
Following a shot, the other team needs to play a "Blocker", "Trapper" or "Post" card.
The game is fairly easy to teach and play, and comes with two difficulty levels.
The rules are a little lame as some questions remain unanswered. Then again, I seem to have the first edition as my box is half the size of the one shown in the Image Gallery.

item.name: Smash Up
item.comment: Only played 3 games. A little too much randomness. Some combos/teams are over powered, but can be mitigated by players (gang up on the leader), which may lead to king making.

item.name: Snifty Snakes
item.comment: A load of laughs, especially when everyone wears those "glasses" with the protruding nose piece! Plays quickly.

item.name: Space Alert
item.comment:
Very thematic, soundtrack adds to the gaming experience. Robotic voice is easy to understand on DVD, and an MP3 file is available for download if you prefer using a PC.
We had two players sitting besides the DVD player, one would handle outside threats, the other inside threats. Worked quite well, as the Communication Officer would repeat the information.
First time out we played [b]TEN[/b] 5-player games in a row (don't recall ever doing that before!), starting off with the intro games and moving up. The self training approach was very nicely done.
Highly recommend this game if you are into coop games. It is a cross between [GAMEID=18] and [GAMEID=12350], in the [GAMEID=31481] universe!

item.name: Space Cadets
item.comment:
Only 1 play, 3-players. Due to the "puzzle" mechanic used at some stations, I was not expecting to like it.
Will be trying it again, with more players.

item.name: Space Dealer
item.comment:
An interesting try at making a "real-time" game. Unfortunately the timers don't have the same amount of sand, and it can be frustrating to see someone beat you at a delivery when everyone appeared to be playing in their own little sand box two timers ago...
Still a neat concept, just not into this type of thing.

item.name: Space Hulk: Death Angel â The Card Game
item.comment:
The action selection mechanic is nice, preventing you from choosing the same action twice.
Each team has one powerful and one regular unit, else the team has a strong team ability.
Good feel of the Space Hulk universe, for a card game.

item.name: Spearpoint 1943
item.comment:
Combat required you roll => then a target # with 2d10. Makes for very random results, which is good, except when one player is very lucky and the other unlucky.
Only played one game, where the US rolled nothing under 12 for his first five rolls, decimating the German units and scoring 32+ points. Germans were unable to hit, even with a to hit number of 9 (rolled 8) until late in the game.
Mechanically the game is OK, although some rules are not clear; case in point, the rulebook has 3 pages of rules and a page of diagrams, and there is a 6 page FAQ...
Cards are good quality and iconography is easy to follow.
Dislikes (apart from random combat):
Sleeved cards will not fit in the original box.
US has mobile artillery (M3 Priest) Germans have none... Find the game unbalanced, advantaging the US.
Simultaneous target selection and commitment of units were sticking points with my opponent, but it didn't impact any of my decisions (either I was going to place a unit or I wasn't, same with target selection, so mechanically this should be fine).

item.name: Star Fleet Battles
item.comment:
The basic system is quite enjoyable, especially if you like 2D naval combat games, which is what this amounts to essentially.
Beware of rules lawyers if you play with several of the expansions. I'd recommend staying away from these as they don't add all that much to the game. The entire rules with the expansion is several hundread pages of 8Â½ x 11 inch paper... Come on, it can't be THAT complex.
Then again, if you're a die hard, then the expansions are a must.

item.name: Star Realms
item.comment:
After 75+ games...
For the price, this is a good game.
It may appear light at first, but there are myriad combos and multiple paths to victory.
Unfortunately, it being a card/deck building game, there is still a sizable luck factor. Will you have the resources to buy those big cards, or will the big cards be available when you have the resources? Will the combos come out together, or in different hands?
Team play looks promising, but requires the purchase of an extra game per two players.
If you like light-medium and fast playing deck building games, it would be a good addition to your collection, as a game can be completed in 20-30 minutes, and it has a relatively small foot print.
If you despise randomness, there may be just a bit too much here you.
But you may try before you buy, as the game is available as a free download for most platforms! So you can learn how to play versus the (easy) computer AI.

item.name: Star Trek Deck Building Game: The Next Generation
Star Trek: Expeditions
item.comment:
Theme is well rendered for a Knizia, but ST:TNG or ST:TOS or even ST:E would have been a better setting. Of course, they could all have been used.
Components are nice, but the "Energize" cards are a tad thin, but the "web" coating helps. Counters and especially the mission cards are made of thick cardboard.
Game play wise, I'm not sure. The mechanic seems Ok, but something does not seem to jive. The space combat is more or less pointless, as unless you get lucky with the die roll, and the Klingon die does not come up with the battlev (repair), nothing much seems to occur. No one selected "Attack" as the odds were that bad.
The actual "Challenges" work Ok, and trying to get the right combination crew can be quite a challenge. Then you add a die roll to all this... The randomness level is fairly high for a Knizia.
The clix is a neat idea, but it is not well suited for this kind of game, IMHO.

item.name: Star Trek: Fleet Captains
item.comment:
The energy management system (ie. cliks) works well and keeps the game simple. The models are nice and detailed.
The cards are very thin, which is Ok as you can sleeve them, but the System location hexes are the same thinkness, which is very sad, as they skimed on the wrong components.
Gameplay is OK, although the Klingons have to be agressive. You may want to move, then adjust your energy level if need be. Scanning is nice, if it's an objective.
Only played one game, with 4 players, and it was a little long, but this is due to inexperience. Will definitely be trying this one again.
Edit: Tried a 3-player game with the Romulan expansion, and we all liked it.
There is one nonsensical rule about winning the game, which disadvantages the first player. If he scores 10 points, then all the other players need to do is match his score to steal the win. You got to be kidding!? Needless to say, we have stricken out this rule.

item.name: Star Trek: Fleet Captains â Romulan Empire
item.comment:
Played a 3-Player game. Works well.
Nice minis. :)
Cards and Location tiles could have been a thicker... (the cards can be sleeved, but seriously, any thinner and we'd see through them?!?).

item.name: Star Wars Miniatures: Starship Battles
item.wantpartslist: 1x #12 Tantive IV, 1 x #22 Obi-Wan's Jedi Interceptor, 1 x #38 Trade Federation Droid Control Ship, X-Wing, Y-Wing, Tie Fighthers, Tie Interceptors and Tie Bombers

item.name: StarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: Played with 2, 3 and 6 players, and each time we did not complete the game (most players decided to stop playing). There are some interesting mechanics (placing order tokens), the pieces are nice, except that those on stands appear prone to break (there were 3 broken units in the game I played - the game was brand new). Further, the "universe/planets" is not thematic and gives an advantage to the attacker. Game appears heavily geared towards combat, yet the combat system is not interesting and too long for what it is.Over all, I was disappointed, and did not object when 3 of the 6 players decided to stop playing.

item.name: Starship Catan
item.comment:
An interesting 2-player game, where one needs to explore sections of the galaxy (4 hidden decks of 10 cards), pick up and deliver goods (your choice, no "orders" cards) in order to generate a profit, which you can then use to upgrade your ship's stores, weapons, propulsion, etc.
There is little interaction between players, other then "seeing" the cards your opponent turns over, and the odd resource trade/theft now and again.
A good filler, if a tad long.

item.name: Stellar Conquest
item.comment: Relatively fast playing spaceploitation game. Somewhat limited in what a player can do. Game ends after a preset number of turns. Not too many different ship types...

item.name: Stock Ticker
item.comment: Fairly basic game, easy to learn and plays fast. Best bet is to buy the penny stocks (under $100), as even an "UP 5" is good !!

item.name: Stone Age
item.comment: Outstanding game, what a Euro should be! Yes there are dice, but you can reduce luck by managing your resources (sending more workers). Except for a few typos (like the use of Tools) the rules are clear and concise. Mechanics and gameplay is clean, yet there are multiple ways to victory. Game scales well with 2-4 players, although I suspect it is best with 4 (played a 3-player game and it remained close!)

item.name: Stratego
item.comment: Used to play a lot in the late 70's. Was an OK game back then. Does not measure up as well with today's game, but can still be fun/challenging if in the right mood and with the right type of player.

item.name: Street Illegal
item.comment: Very annoying and pointless game. Tried twice, and there will not be a third. Would suggest playing MILLE BORNES instead.

item.name: StreetSoccer
item.comment:
Easy to learn and quick to play. A tad too random for me, but if you replaced the d6 by an average die (2-3-3-4-4-5), it would probably be more interesting, and less random!
As it is, a "6" is almost always a goal, while a "1" can put you in serious trouble, and both have little to do with where your "players" are located on the field.
Other then that, a great idea/concept, but it needs a little more polishing.

item.name: Submarine
item.comment: Good Submarine simulation. Solo scenario available. Each turn represents about 50 seconds. Somewhat unrealistic intelligence for the submarine player in FTF games, but this is easily overcome with a GM. Lends itself very well for PBeM!

item.name: Sucking Vacuum
item.comment:
Rating based on a single 6-player game...
Too many players, too much down time between turns. Theme is interesting, but some of the weapons (Stuffed Bear, Cat, Microscope) are just, well, boring.
It is a self-published game, so although the components look nice, the cardboard tokens are way too thin and difficult to pick up when playing on a smooth surface.

item.name: SuDoku: Das Kartenspiel
item.comment:
A fairly easy game, especially if you have solved SuDoku puzzles before. Of course it is NOT exactly like the 9x9 grid, but rather centers around the placement of cards around other cards, the yellow cards being used as the center of a 3x3 section.
Players score points (a bad thing) when he/she cannot place a card on the table/grid.
[u]Strategy[/u]: Hold on to your yellow cards until you can no longer place any of your blues. This may force the opponents to take penalty points because they can't place theirs, as yellow cards tend to open up the game.
[u]Card count[/u]: 9 yellow, 45 blue Sadly, you don't have enough to use this deck to solve regular Sudoku puzzles. That's too bad as it would have gotten extra points for that.

item.name: Supremacy
item.comment:
An economic, political war game, where you will most likely see nuclear war. The components are nice (mounted board, plastic playing pieces, paper money), and the game play is Ok, if you like this genre.
The economic system is a bit lame, the advantage going to the player who plays first (advanced and/or house rules may aleviate this).
Combat is relatively straight forward, and the political system is similar to Risk, in that it's via player interaction only.
Still a game I don't mind playing now and again, especially with the larger map and several of the expansions!

item.name: Supremacy: Field Marshall's Handbook
item.comment: Adds a lot of optional rules. Too bad they did not include a fix to the market, which I find sways too much.

item.name: Sutter's Mill
item.comment:
Perhaps we did not play this right, as my experience was not enjoyable at all. The mechanics are simple, but there appears to be a combo available to the first player, and the last player seems rather disadvantaged.
In any event, I was able to place a few (4) cards, but was not able to pull them out without giving more points to my opponents. Our 4-player game ended with a score of 87, -2, -6 and -20. With only one player scoring positively....
The mechanic of having to move your pawns to town in order to collect gold tokens, then having to pay to move them back to the mine(s) is quite clean and works well.
On the other hand, the mechanic of adding cards to take control of town buildings and then trying to remove them or suffering negative points, does not work at all.
Rating should have been a 1, but I just love the Phalanx game components. Still, you won't catch me dead playing this again.

item.name: Taboo
item.comment: May be interesting with the right group. Would recommend at least 6 for this to be enjoyable. It's OK with less, but only when teaching the game.

item.name: Taluva
item.comment: This is a light game, with great components! My rating is low simply because it's not the type I prefer, but it does make for a good filler if you have 30-40 minutes.

item.name: TannhÃ¤user
item.comment:
I picked up the French version yesterday (Feb.17/2007). Here's a brief synopsis:
First off, gameplay is OK. Appart from the neat "Pathfinder" idea, there is nothing new here. FYI, "Pathfinder" is what they have called the color coding they have applied to each circle (space) which eliminates the need to check Line of Sight.
The 10 character pieces are pre-painted and the details are good. The mounted board comes in four sections *which DO NOT inter-lock), and is double side, limiting you to two maps. Expansions are alreay underway/planned. The item and weapon tokens are nice and big, and each character board (with stats, etc.) are mounted. That's right, mounted, just like the board is.
The combat system is very similar to that of Heroscape, with the addition of counter-attacking, at the cost of 1 victory point.
The glossy paper rulebook is in full color, but I find they go into too much detail on the basic stuff.
The one thing this game is SCREAMING for is a player aid. Actually, without a player aid it becomes a pain to play, as you need to refer to each character's "kit" in the rulebook in order to know the advantages each item and weapon provides.
My initial rating of 6 is after a single play in Deathmatch mode. I don't foresee the other three modes/level of difficulty (Story, Catch The Flag, Domination) affecting my rating positively.

item.name: Target Earth
item.comment:
Game play is simple enough once you get around the terrible translation of what should be simple rules.
The tokens were difficult to remove from the sprue, which resulted in a few being damaged.
The game is a ripoff of an old favorite PC tile, X-COM:UFO DEFENCE, minus the cool tactical squad combat.
Playing time is closer to 2 hours, but with 10+ games, I'm sure it can be done in 90 minutes.
All in all, it is a risk management game, with a lot of die rolling. Replay value may appear low to some, as you are always doing the same thing, for 7 turns, which tougher aliens.
It is, unfortunately, rather pricey for what you get.

item.name: Tchin Tchin
item.comment: A quick filler, which becomes repetitive rather quickly. Person with quicker reflexes, who can say the correct word and make the correct motion, wins the point. Person with most point wins... That's about it.

item.name: Terakh: A Creative Strategy Game
item.comment:
A mix of DUNGEON TWISTER and CHESS. Each player has limited actions, which prevents the game from bogging down too much with more players.
For a first design, the quality of the components is impressive, right up to the felt underneath the waxed triangular boards!
Some luck is involved, in that a d8 is rolled in combat. The addition of Cast Cards can tip the balance in your favor, so you need to plan when you will be using them, as some require you to have a unit on a specific colored tile (called Tria).
Each player has access to an ORB, which can be combined with one of his INKA (3D circular pawn), turning it into a powerful IDOL (Hero). This Idol gains experience whenever his team wins a battle. XP is taken as a +1 modifier to either combat or defense. An Idol may not have more than 3 XP, so you need to decide if it will be used Offensively, Defensively, or a combination of both.
Eliminated pieces can be "resurected", so a player is never out of the game, although his/her available actions are limited when he/she loses his leader (ELDER).
The game ends when only one ELDER (represented by a d4) remains, all the others having lost all four of their hit points.

item.name: Thebes
item.comment: This is a good family game. The time management system is great, and ensures quick turns. Drawing tiles from the different bags and returning the "sand" tiles after the dig makes it even more interesting for the kids.

item.name: The Thief of Baghdad
item.comment: Easy to learn, but requires a few plays to see the possible combinations. May be difficult to block other players. Expect to be holding a lot of cards. There is an element of luck, as you need to draw the right cards in order to place your pawns were you'd like, else you try to make the best with what you have.

item.name: Third World Debt
item.comment: Really crappy components, not worth the asking price! Rules were on a single sheet, and were a very bad photocopy, which missed sections at the top, bottom and sides of the sheet... A rip off!

item.name: Three-Dragon Ante
item.comment: Sorry, I just did not like this one. Perhaps it's the D&D rapprochement, or just the powers on the cards themselves that turned me off this title, I donno.

item.name: Through the Ages: A Story of Civilization
item.comment:
This is a card based game of Sid Meier's Civilization (certainly feels like it!). If you enjoyed the PC version, there is no reason not to like this one!
The game flows well, but the full game takes about 6 hours to complete.
Seems to suffer from the runaway leader problem, as in a 3-player game our scores were close when around the 90 point mark, but the end was... well see for yourself:
238, 175 and 159
Still trying to understand what went wrong and why such a large point spread. The person in the lead was ahead in every field, something which felt rather odd. Perhaps she just had better card selections, as none of us lost a turn switching Gov't types, yet the spread between 1st and 2nd was 63 points (~30%), and with last it's 79 points (or ~50% of his points!?)
item.conditiontext: 2nd edition (with 315 wooden bits and the "CE" sticker)

item.name: Thunderstone Advance: Root of Corruption
item.comment:
The co-op rules work pretty well.
What THUNDERSTONE should have been.

item.name: Thunderstone: Dragonspire
item.comment: Too many expansions... You need to be careful as to what is available in town, as it can ruin your gaming experience (make the game too long) if the items don't match with at least one Hero class...

item.name: Thunderstone: Wrath of the Elements
item.comment:
Played my first 3-player game with the expansion using the recommended setup, and was rather disappointed... Perhaps this was due to the fact that the monsters which came up first were too strong, as I was unable to go to the dungeon until I had a deck of 42 cards... We start with 12, so that's 30 turns later.
Will be playing it again, but for now it's a disappointment.

item.name: Thurn and Taxis
item.comment:
After one play. Was 3rd in a 4-player game, and had the impression the 1st and 2nd player had a leg up on me as they would always score the higher point tiles/counters before me. Perhaps my approach was bad? Willing to give this one another try.
The cards are too small, but the rest of the gaming material is good. Nice drawings on the cards, wooden houses.

item.name: Ticket to Ride
item.comment:
An easy "euro" type game (no dice). Players draw cards and attempt to build railroad segments between cities to score points. These segments are built using color coded cards. As an example, one needs to hand in a set of colored cards equal to the lenght and color of the track one wants to build/own between two cities.
Tickets are double edged, in that they provide you with extra points if you complete the route listed on the ticket, else you loose the points.
Once a player's markers (45) are reduced to less than 3, the last turn of the game is played, then the points are counted and compared to find a winner.
Player interaction is limited, although one may block another player by building a segment of track which he/she thinks the other player needs in order to complete a ticket.

item.name: Ticket to Ride: The Card Game
item.comment: Not overly impressed with this one as it is more a memory game than anything else.

item.name: Timbuktu
item.comment:
A deduction game where one will get three pieces of information out of time over the course of the turn. One must move his/her camels in the spots where there is no robber, or their camel does not carry what the robber is after.
Fairly straight forward, but can be long when played with analytical people. Components are nice. Not my type of game.

item.name: Time's Up!
item.comment: A good party game. Played in three rounds; first round you are allowed to give as many clues as possible in order to have your team guess the word/personality. In the second round, you can only give 1 clue (then again you should know which cards are in the play deck). Third round you cannot speak, but must act out what's on the card. Can get hillarious.

item.name: Timeline: Inventions
item.comment:
A quick filler, and informative too! Who would have known the Cross-Bow was invented way back then??
Looking to pick up a copy, even though I think the replay value is limited as players will tend to remember each invention's year.

item.name: Tinners' Trail
item.comment:
An excellent "medium" level game which is easy to learn, but still contains difficult choices and a few tactical subtleties.
The market fluctuation (semi-random) works well, and I especially like the water mechanism which increases the price to exploit the mine (similar to the sand in Thebes). One has to spend time removing the water in order to reduce operating costs, so you are trying to maximize the cost to revenue ratio.
The "time" mechanic also appears to stem from Thebes, and it works quite well in this game.
Last but not least, one has to purchase VP using your cash, which is usually not plentiful. This forces players to make tough choices are the earlier you spend money on the "External Markets", the more VP they represent.
#901

item.name: Top Dogs
item.comment: This is probably a good kids game, teaching additions and multiplacations, although there is not much of a game here...

item.name: Top Race
item.wishlistcomment: Looking for Magma Ãditions version. Interest level: 4 - Thinking about it

item.name: Trajan
item.comment:
A mix of several worker placement mechanics, plus set building. The "bowl" can be a brain burner, as it forces you to plan a few (3) turns ahead.
Possibility of action combos with Trajan and Building Tiles. Will you be going for the bonus action, or pick up that Building tile which will hopefully allow you to have a set of 3 or 4 at the end of the game (and score a bonus 10 or 20 points)?
Some interesting decisions, and you can't really be blocked, although other players can pick up a title you were looking to get.
The "people's demand" is a nice clean mechanic which forces you to allocate a few actions in order to secure the needed tiles (forum or military) or Trajan permanent tiles (which are only worth 1 VP but will end up saving you time/actions).
The "time clock" allows for 2, 3 or 4 player configurations.
In the end, it's all about scoring points.

item.name: Tri-Ominos
item.comment: This was probably a good game in the 60's, but there are much better games out there. Then again, for under $15, it could be worthwhile to some.

item.name: Trieste
item.comment:
Played 3 games. Seems very easy for the Merchant player to win, he just draws Treasure cards... Yet City Watch did win, once we added in the Heroes.
Game plays very quickly. A fast filler.

item.name: Troyes
item.comment:
Wasn't convinced after the first play; second play confirmed this was a stinker. 2 points for the nice art and three language rulebook (French, German, English).
Game is way too long for what it is, an advanced worker placement game, in which you can become a spectator after the 1st turn (out of 6).
Re-read the rules (in both French and English) after first game to ensure we were playing this correctly. Perhaps we just had unlucky event draws?? With no influence to modify/re-roll poor dice rolls, and not enough cash to make a decent die combo, was relegated to the status of spectator, trying to wrestle workers from other players who had Influence, Workers and cash to spare.... Uphill battle to attempt to stay on the positive side of the VP score...
Started off with 4 "Workers" in town, lost 3 (max you can lose in a turn) due to other player placements/actions, and managed to recoup one.
Started 2nd turn with 2 workers (dice), Influence wiped out by event, 7$, and attacking units tied up 1 out of 2 dice. With my last die, was able to place one worker, and I lost 1 during the turn, thus down to two at start of 3rd turn.
Influence event still in force, wiped out my Influence, again. "Invading" units wiped out my dice. With one point of influence, little money, and no dice to generate income, I had to pass after trying to get another worker in town... Half the game gone, 2 VP showing....
Finished the game with 3 VP, about 25 points behind 3rd place. Was never able to recoup the loss of 3 dice in the 1st turn.
Game winner, in both games, was the player with the most dice, from turn to turn. Out of 4 players, 2 are in the race to win, the other 2 are unable to catch up and are mere spectators.
Will not be playing this one again. For trade.

item.name: Tumblin-Dice
item.comment:
A light party game where folks of all ages can play!
It is a dexterity game, which mixes in a bit of curling, as you can (try) to position your dice to block those in good scoring position, or "take out" those of your opponents.
A bit pricey for what is it, but it will keep the kids busy (even the adults).

item.name: Twilight Imperium (second edition)
item.comment: Some good ideas, but too much bookeeping. It was a good game at the time. Fleets get way too large, and richer players can simply steam roll everyone else, or the political cards screw them over by destroying all their dreadnoughts...

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition)
item.comment: There are some good ideas in this game, unfortunately it is very dependent on the setup you have and the race you've picked. A low tech race with low resource planets besides a high tech race with twice your resources turns into a waste of 5 hours, unless the other races can gang up. Very dependent on player experience and willingness to negotiate. It is a political game after all.

item.name: Twilight Imperium (Third Edition): Shattered Empire
item.comment: There are some good ideas in this game, unfortunately it is very dependent on the setup you have and the race you've picked. A low tech race with low resource planets besides a high tech race with twice your resources turns into a waste of 5 hours, unless the other races can gang up. Very dependent on player experience and willingness to negotiate. It is a political game after all.
item.conditiontext: Shrink

item.name: Twilight Struggle
item.comment:
Rating may be a little low, as I've only played a single game as the US and was literally wiped out by the USSR player by turn #4, and he appeared to do so effortlessly...
It would seem that although we were both new (we were initially coached by a avid fan of the game), he grasped something I did not, which resulted in my demise. The part I missed was how the cards get recycled back into the deck, and that one is better off not playing his events. You see, the game is all about doing the right thing at the right time, and preventing your opponent from doing the same. In order to have a good grasp of this game, one needs to be aware of all the cards, as well as their impact. I'm pretty sure my rating will go up after I've played this a few more times.

item.name: USAC Auto Racing
item.comment: A tad too simplistic, and cars break down too easily, especially when one pushes the engine.

item.name: Valley of the Mammoths
item.comment:
A light game where event cards make pre-planning your moves next to impossible. Fortune cards keep the game fresh as your opponents have no idea what your tribe can do to respond to an attack. Need to be in the right mood to play this.
The game is centered on gathering food in order to survive and expand your tribe.
There is a lot of randomness, but it keeps the game interesting.
If your tribe can survive the first winter, then you're doing something right ;-)

item.name: Vasco da Gama
item.comment:
I just love resource/action management games with inter-locking decision mechanics, which this game possesses.
Game components are excellent, except for the "Captain" pawns, which are too small (ie. easy to loose).

item.name: Victory: The Blocks of War
item.comment:
This is a generic wargame in a WWII setting. Scale is closer to Strategic than it is to Tactical. Due to this it may appear to be bland to some players, but it is most excellent for those who like Strategic scale type games.
The block system is quite ingenious and offers very good fog-of-war, not to mention there is no need to record anything as it is all done using the blocks (and rotating them to record hits/damage).
Each unit is rated for Air, Land, Sea (combat) and Movement, which results in units having different specialties. In turn, this provides the units with certain advantages and disadvantages.
Combat system is also interesting; it is an advanced version of what is seen in Axis & Allies, with priority given to faster units, the defender always firing first when both players have the same type of units present.
Combat system rewards combined arms approach, and requires multiple waves to break through a well-defended area. If your attack is not well planned and supported, it will most likely fail, especially if the dice Gods are not on your side. Advantage goes to the low rollers ;-)
Recommend getting the ELITE expansion, which adds more units. The map expansions are also good to have.
Down side: The game can bog down with multiple players as there is not much interaction except for the "Air Response" phase during which the defender can move air units (and Mech units with the ELITE expansion) to an area under attack.
Expect a lot of die rolling.
The entire game system can be rather costly.
Lastly, all units cost the same. Making a house rule to alleviate this is relatively straightforward.

item.name: Victory: The Blocks of War â Elite Blocksets
Victory: The Blocks of War â Extra Maps
Victory: The Blocks of War â Logistics Set
Vikings
item.comment: Easy to teach and learn. The "cost wheel" system works really well; I like it!.

item.name: Wallenstein (first edition)
item.comment: Good game, near order selection mechanic. Expect some down time during your first game or two, as players get acquainted with the limited choices they have! The wargame aspect is very minor, and the tower of death makes combat resolution instantaneous. Unfortunately, I'd prefer dice, as the tower can prove problematic if someone bangs the table (accidentally or not)

item.name: The War Game: World War II
item.comment:
Obviously an Axis & Allies variant, which includes some improvements and unfortunately, some major flaws as well. Then again, perhaps we did not play this correctly, but as is the Axis simply have no chance whatsoever to win, unless they have lucky die rolls and their opponents do not. Feels like A&A with someone's house rules, where everything from A&A is doubled, more or less...
Some of the positive points: - Nicely detailed units (too bad they are all German) - Nice board (a tad too big though) - China has its own units!
Some of the negative points: - After the first turn, Germany's attack versus Russia simply stalls. The Japanese can wipe out the US Pacific Fleet at Pearl Harbor, only to see the US spring up a larger fleet in a single turn.
With income levels over 100 (Germany starts at 127, USA at 147) it becomes an accounting nightmare (there is no chart, so accounting is done using pen and paper or poker chips in our case).
- The board is too large (6' wide would have sufficed) - No variety in unit molds (they are all German - Infantry, tanks, planes, ships, etc.) - One has to cut each unit off the sprues (time consuming and teadious) - Some units were damaged in transit (broken off gun on tanks, infantry, etc.) - Some units are not well formed and/or are too brittle (88's with missing/broken "leg") - Some units don't "sit" well (subs usually lie on their side, CV bottom is not flat, fighters are too big to sit on the CV, BB is a tad small, Transport and DD difficult to distinguish from afar - the board is over 6' long!) - Unit color choices are bad for color blind gamers (USSR and China, even USA and Germany gave non-color blind players some issues?) - Cardboard components, other then the map, are too thin, and warp badly. - The rule which allows one to spring up Infantry anywhere on the board simply makes little sense, and breaks the game even further! - Too many sectors/zones - Way too long to set up! - Fairly easy for the Axis to take control of the Med. - China is now pretty tough to crack. - Only 5 d12 included with the game - Rulebook in B&W, color version available online (this is a $100 game...) - Advanced rules available for an additional $25...
Although I wanted to like this game, I find A&A better, faster and cleaner.

item.name: War! Age of Imperialism
item.comment:
The board is quite nice, although my gaming group found that Europe was simply too small for the number of units stationed there.
Expect a lot of record keeping and counting.
The research tree is a nice addition, which adds to the record keeping and time.
The battle resolution system is very simple.
For a more interesting game, I suggest using the battle system from the ACW game. It does add 5-10 minutes per battle, but is more realistic IMO.

item.name: WarCraft: The Board Game
item.comment: Played a 2-player game (Elves vs. Orcs) and found it interesting. Game plays relatively fast and the resource reduction works well as it forces players to be agressive. The "experience" cards add a touch of uncertainty as you are never certain if your army is stronger than your opponent until the battle starts and cards are played. An interesting and playable concept. Game pieces are generic but don't impact the enjoyment of the game. As for lenght, our first game was under 2 hours, including setup and a few rules check.

item.name: Wars of the Roses: Lancaster vs. York
item.comment:
A very nicely produced game! Excellent quality components.
Simultaneous action selection is what attracted me to this one. Period feel is also pretty good. Only thing missing is fun. It's an area majority game brimming with chaos. Everything can be "bought" so the limiting factor is money...
Problem is the "French Aid", which allows trailing players to get back in the game by providing them with money. So, it rewards players for scoring low, by providing them with a large (up to $25) influx of money. Money adds more flexibility/options, which in turn adds more chaos...
Unfortunately, French Aid is, IMHO, a game breaker.
If you keep your income mid-range for the first two turns, and your points low, you'll have an excellent chance at the win. On the turn you receive the $20-25 cash influx, attack your opponents income base to essentially take them out of the game.
Imagine you are the leader, having concentrated on an economic strategy, and you are generating $23 a turn. The player in last place has an income of $15, but a VP spread of 25 with first place... He gets two good card picks (1st and 5th cards out of 8), AND an additional $25, bringing his income to $40 on that turn. He then proceeds to attack your economic base. Next turn you are generating 11, and he's at $40 again. You are now relegated to the status of spectator, until your point spread allows you to benefit from French Aid...
So you want to keep your points low, in a game where it is rather difficult to predict just how many points you will be able to (not) generate. This simply does not work for me.
Don't get me wrong, I am a wargamer at heart, and I like a good dose of chaos (dice, cards, etc.) but in WotR, it's over the top.
Ok, it's easy to complain and bicker, so how could we fix this?
How about adding TWO cards to the card row at the start of the turn, and allowing the player who's requesting French Aid to get the first two picks instead? This would reduce the chaos produced by a sudden influx of $25, in a game already brimming with chaos.
If more than one player requests French Aid, then allow them to alternate picking their TWO bonus cards.
In the above proposal, the option to request French Aid should only be open to players with a point spread of 10+ with the leader.
My two cents.

item.name: Wealth of Nations
item.comment: Speculation with a working market system. Expect downtime during the Trade phase as players buy, sell and trade goods. Interesting hex shaped industry tiles which use "full circles" as a means to measure production level. The more contiguous your group of tiles of the same industry are, the more production it will generate.

item.name: Werewolf
item.comment: A fairly interesting game for a LARGE group. Can be rather boring and long if you are one of the first to be killed... Else, it's a game of deduction, suspicion, and if you're a WereWolf, you support whomever's accusations to add oil to the fire!

item.name: The Werewolves of Miller's Hollow
item.comment:
First off I am not a big fan of games like this, but don't mind giving it a try at a convention. The game does require a lot of players, and we were 21 at the game I played.
The game can be enjoyable with the "right" type of players, and a smaller ranther than larger group, else the debates become endless. Game Master must be strick on time and force a "vote" after the time is up.
This is the same as [GAMEID=925].

item.name: WeyKick
item.comment: A great party game, which requires at least four players, but is best with six. Magnets are not strong enough to hold the figures on the board when one does abrupt moves, but I find this adds to the game, as you rush to get your "player" back on it's magnet.

item.name: Wings
item.comment: Highly detailed WWI Air Combat game. Each turn represents 4 seconds.

item.name: Wings of War: Burning Drachens
item.comment:
This is the third game in the WINGS OF WAR series. This one includes advanced rules, which include AAA, MG fire, Trench fire, strafing, bombing, recon and balloon busting missions, to name only those. You will also find interesting rules on altitude and clouds! I still prefer the simplicity of the altitude rules and flight constraints in CANVAS EAGLES.
If you'd like to see what the WoW series is like, this is the game to get.
This one can be played by 1-2 players, thus solo play is possible.
And yes, it meshes very well with the other two games in the series. Now all we need is a bigger box to store all the pieces!

item.name: Wings of War: Famous Aces
item.comment:
A fast playing air combat game. Each turn players pick three maneuvers they will be performing, and players reveal each maneuver simultaneously, then resolve any combat before playing the next one.
There are only 4 decks of maneuver cards, which means that one cannot fly two planes of the same type unless one picks up another copy of the game or the maneuvers are written.
After five plays, then cards got sticky. Using card protectors of some sort would not be all that great as it would make moving more troublesome.
I concur with Jody about the punch being off centered.
One thing which prevents this game from hitting my gaming table more often is the problem with ensuring the cards don't move and/or stick to your hand.

item.name: Wings of War: Watch Your Back!
item.comment:
Fast playing tactical air game. The maneuver cards are Ok, but it can be a tad fiddly to move when planes overlap... [thing=10501][/thing] is head-and-shoulders above this title, and includes altitude and a light campaign system.
Of course the miniature planes of this series can be used for [thing=10501][/thing]!
item.conditiontext: Mint, still in shrink-wrap. Would prefer to sell or trade as a set with: - Famous Aces - Burning Drachens

item.name: Winner's Circle
item.comment: Not much game here, although an interesting mechanic around a betting game.

item.name: Witch of Salem
item.comment:
Relatively easy to learn and play, coop game. Kind of an Arkham Horror "light".
Game plays well, and you are usually done within an hour. It is not an easy task to win, as some of the info (portals) you collect may NOT be shared with the other players.

item.name: Wits & Wagers
item.comment:
This is a good trivia game, even if you're not a fan of such games. All the answers will be numeral, and you don't need to know all the answers as questions are answered by all players simultaneously, on a white card (using a dry erase marker).
The player answers are then laid out on the "Wagers" board (excellent quality BTW!), in incremental order, which will provide the various answers with anything from 1:1 odds all the way up to 4:1 odds. Players may then wager on the answer they think is the best one, without having gone over.
After seven rounds, the game ends, the player with the most money wins.
The game may appear to be a tad short, but you can adjust this if you'd like. A good "party" filler game.

item.name: Wizard Kings
item.comment:
Wargame in a Fantasy setting. Block system is great for fog-of-war. Combat system rather straight forward.
As I'm not a fan of fantasy type games, you should take my rating with a grain of salt. ;-)

item.name: World of Warcraft: The Boardgame
item.comment:
I'm not an adventure gamer, but did not mind this game at all. It is a tad long, but being a wargamer, 4 hours is standard. Although there can be some downtime when one player is engaged in combat, I find there is always something to do, so it's not boring down time. The components are excellent, and the mechanics work well. The game oozes with theme.
The combat system may appear bizarre at first, but after you've played through one, it becomes intuitive.
The PvP aspect is something I do not particularly care for, as I feel it does not add to the game, but was added so it mimics the on-line game.

item.name: Wreckage
item.comment: Quick playing smash up derby type game. The movement is akin of that of a miniatures game, with ruler and angle.

item.name: Wyatt Earp
item.comment: Easy to learn and play. Rulebook was rather hard to follow, but after a few rounds, it became clear.

item.name: XCOM: The Board Game
item.comment:
Only played twice, at easy, and really like it. Not a fan of App Assisted games, especially time constrained ones.
Nice component but should have included 2 more blue dice.
Not a fan of push-your-luck mechanic, but it works really well here!
The game is built around the theme, but its really a Euro Worker placement and resource management game.

item.name: Xia: Legends of a Drift System
You're Bluffing!
item.comment: Not really my type, but could be convinced to play when in the right mood. Interesting bidding/stealing mechanic (with the blind bid).

item.name: Zero!
item.comment:
The concept of fighting an air combat using cards to counter each others actions is quite interesting, not to mention the Leader-Wingman rules work rather well.
A scenario/battle can be played in under 30 minutes, while a campaign will easily fit in one afternoon. Anti-Aircraft and bombing/torpedoing rules also work well. The designers did an awesome job of fitting everything on the cards, which are used to resolve everything!
The "Corsairs and Hellcats" expansion is more expensive then this game, which makes no sense.
BTW, Zero is missing 4 "Full Throttle" cards, which are included in the expansion (or you can order them directly from GMT).

item.name: ZÃRTZ
item.comment: Unfortunately, I do not enjoy the shrinking board mechanic. Seems to be a cross between Checkers and something else...

item.name: Zombie Fluxx
item.comment: What do you expect from a game where the rules are in constant fluxx? ;) The Creepers adds an extra level of complexity to a simplistic game.
